    The History of Kubernetes
    Kubernetes can speed up the development process by making easy, automated deployments, updates (rolling-update) and by managing our apps and services with almost zero downtime. Kubernetes evolved from an internal container orchestration solution at Google to the tool that we know today. To begin our Kubernetes history, we must begin with Google. Google faced a major issue in the early 2000s. While they continued to dominate the majority of the digital world, they were still figuring out how to make revenue from their extensive number of free services. This included popular services like: Google Search YouTube Gmail The problem for Google, which was not the profit-making machine we know today, was finding a way to offer these free services without tanking the business. Keep in mind that‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )
    Debugging a Wordle Bug
    I have a confession: I'm addicted to Wordle. Especially now that it's out of style and people don't post about it. I love that it's short, I can solve one word and then it's gone. I don't feel too bad about the addiction and wasting my time with a game. This cloud debugger tutorial is an enormous challenge for me since the target is a Wordle game. But I'm getting ahead of myself. As part of the Lightrun Playground we recently released we needed a demo application that will let developers who are new to Lightrun, practice in a "safe environment".We decided to pick Wordle as our demo application because it's instantly familiar, visual and not too interactive. A Flappy Bird demo might have been painful to debug. At this point our key challenge was in creating a bug where the debugging process‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )
    Go generics ‡πÉ‡∏ô gin Handler
    ‡πÄ‡∏ô‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å Go 1.18 ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ generic ‡πÅ‡∏•‡πâ‡∏ß ‡∏ã‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ô block ‡∏Å‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏ô‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ ‡∏ú‡∏°‡∏Å‡πá‡∏ô‡∏≥‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏≤ blog ‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏â‡∏ö‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á contributors ‡∏°‡∏≤‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ß‡πÜ‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏≠‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏£‡∏π‡πâ usecases ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ generic ‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏õ‡∏Å‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏à‡∏∞‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö ‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡πà‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö map, slice ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠ channel ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏Å ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏á‡πÜ ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÜ usecases ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏°‡∏≤ ‡∏°‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö interface ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤ ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏û‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏¢‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏≤ generic ‡πÉ‡∏™‡πà‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ó‡πà ‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏Å‡πá‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢‡∏•‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ generic ‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á gin HandlerFunc ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ô handler ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏á‡πà‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏´‡∏ô‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏ì‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ func Handler(request) (response,error) ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡πÇ‡∏¢‡∏ä‡∏ô‡πå‡∏Å‡πá‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠ ‡∏°‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏ó‡∏™‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ handler ‡∏á‡πà‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á mock gin.Context ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏á‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏õ‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏à‡πá‡∏Ñ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡πÅ‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ domain ‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏à‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏° business logic ‡∏ó‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡∏´‡∏°‡∏î ginhandlerfunc ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô converter ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏á handler ‡πÅ‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡πÑ‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô gin.HandlerFunc ‡πÄ‚Ä¶  ( 4 min )
    The importance of canonical URLs
    I noticed I'm always talking about canonical tags when advising fellow bloggers, but I never wrote this down on paper. So here we go, an article explaining why you should always use canonical tags when republishing your content elsewhere. Let's first set a use case. You are reading this article from one of the following three sources. my blog (daily-dev-tips.com) hashnode dev.to All these three sources have the same content. Let's say your blog does just that. How does Google know which blog to redirect to? If you don't provide a canonical tag, Google might even think you are spamming the internet and not showing any of the three sites! However, you can use this canonical tag to set which site is the primary source for this article. So what do I do, you ask? So how do we set these canonical URLs If you are not using a custom website as your primary source, you can set the canonical URL by adding the following tag in your HTML head. This will tell the search engines they can find the original content on the address you provide there. Most blogging platforms offer a more visual way of adding these canonical tags. For instance, on Hashnode, they have the following widget in the sidebar. And the same kind of graphical element exists on dev.to. A small side note is that my good friend Graham suggests you wait two weeks before reposting your content. This is, in theory, true. Reposting content is a great way to reach a broader audience, but it can hurt your SEO if you don't use canonical tags. Do use canonical tags to indicate to search engines which is your original content. Do not mix the canonicals to link to different articles from different sources. Thank you for reading my blog. Feel free to subscribe to my email newsletter and connect on Facebook or Twitter  ( 5 min )
    How to install Tailwind CSS inside a Next.js project
    In this tutorial you will learn how to set up Tailwind CSS inside a Next.js project and optionally also install the Flowbite React package to get started with open-source components. Disclaimer: this tutorial has been first published on the Tailwind CSS Next.js integration guide from the Flowbite Docs. Next.js is a popular web development framework based on the React library that enables server-side rendering and generating static websites improving development time and website performance. This technology is being used by hundreds of thousands of developers and companies such as Vercel, Netflix, TikTok, Twitch, Hulu, Nike and HBO Max since its original release in 2016. By following this guide you will learn how to properly set up Tailwind CSS with the Flowbite React components inside an e‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    Advanced Node.js Topics:¬†Caching.
    Improve your Server Performance By Caching often Fetched Data using Redis. Introduction: Redis is an in-memory database that stores data in key: value format, since it‚Äôs in memory, it's ridiculously fast. Redis provides data structures such as strings, hashes, lists, sets, sorted sets Redis is an open source (BSD licensed), in-memory data structure store used as a database, cache, message broker, and streaming engine. Redis provides data structures such as strings, hashes, lists, sets, sorted sets with range queries, bitmaps, hyperloglogs, geospatial indexes, and streams. Redis has built-in replication, Lua scripting, LRU eviction, transactions, and different levels of on-disk persistence, and provides high availability via Redis Sentinel and automatic partitioning with Redis ‚Ä¶  ( 8 min )
    Let's Nuke AWS - Account
    DAY 36 - Let‚Äôs Nuke AWS - Day Thirty-Six 100 days of Cloud on GitHub - Read On iCTPro.co.nz - Read on Dev.to Make sure you remove the account from the organisations. Get your access keys for CLI , check out this link to see How to Now Goto repository, clink on releases, select your appropriate file, and right-click copy. Topic Link Clone repo Link Releases Link I am using Linux so selecting cloud-nuke_linux_amd64, Now on your system create a folder called nuke, then cd into it wget https://github.com/gruntwork-io/cloud-nuke/releases/download/v0.16.2/cloud-nuke_linux_amd64 Check the folder once copied the file us ls lets rename the folder to aws-nuke mv cloud-nuke_linux_amd64 aws-cloud Change folder permissions sudo chmod 777 aws-nuke lets copy this to /usr/bin sudo cp aws-nuke /usr/bin verify the package aws-nuke You will be able to similar result as shown in the screenshot Now lets enter the magic command aws-nuke aws We are not done yet, It will preview all the services gonna be destroyed you will be prompted to confirm.... nuke confirm by typing nuke ‚úÖConnect with me on Twitter Linkedin dev.to or iCTPro.co.nz GitHub Anuvindh SankaravilasamFollow Experienced Cloud Technology Specialist with a demonstrated skillset of working with Medical Service , NZ Police & Education industry  ( 7 min )
    I Created A Simple 1 To 1 Meeting Tool
    Introduction Hello! I recently heard about the PlanetScale X Hashnode hackathon, so I thought I'd give it a try. I decided to create a simple 1 to 1 meeting tool using WebRTC. The tech that was used to create the project is as follows: React - To build the frontend Nodejs - To build the backend Express - To handle API requests Socket.io - To handle WebSocket chat/signalling PlanetScale - The database Material-ui - For the design Heroku - To host the app The page that the user is first greeted with when loading the app is the create room page: Yes, I know it's very simple. üòÖ The user can then create a new room by clicking on the "Create Room" button, this sends a request to the server which then creates a new room and stores the room key inside the planetscale database. Once the room ‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    Unit testing frontend code is (probably) useless
    I love unit tests. Magic and its satellite projects has 1,000+ unit tests, and some of the satellite projects even has 100% unit test coverage. Statically analysing code using automation is (duh!) kind of important to us. However, unit testing frontend code is quite frankly (probably) ridiculous. Unit tests are for small units of logic, to automatically ensure that your code is (still) valid as you refactor it, and/or add features to it. If you put logic that requires unit testing into your frontend code, you are probably doing something wrong. 90% of all projects I have worked with in my professional life were enterprise administration tools, and/or customer facing websites, hubs, and registration forms, etc. If you put business logic into these frontend projects, you risk that some smart‚Ä¶  ( 9 min )
    Currying Existing Functions with JavaScript
    This post is about transforming an already defined polyadic function into a curried function. This is the third post in a series on curried functions titled Curry Functions in JavaScript. This follows the previous post named Basic Curried Functions in JavaScript. Basic curried functions are different from more advanced ones because basic currying doesn't involve taking a function as an argument, whereas more advanced ones do. Basic curried functions are defined from scratch, whereas advanced currying involves using an already existing multary function. From a higher level, currying is more of an approach of transforming an otherwise uncurried function to return a series of unary functions - regardless of whether it is hardcoded by the author or transformed at runtime. We will consider seve‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )

    ‰ΩøÁî®ÁªÑÂêàÈîÆÔºå‰Ω†‰∏ç‰ºöË¢´ÈîÆÁõòÊâÄÈôêÂà∂‰Ωè„ÄÇ ÂÖ∏ÂûãÁöÑÈîÆÁõòÂè™ÊúâÁ∫¶ 100 ‰∏™ÈîÆ‰Ωç„ÄÇ Áî±‰∫é¬†Shift¬†ÈîÆÔºåËÆ∏Â§öÈîÆÂæó‰ª•Êúâ‰∏§‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶Ôºà‰πüÁß∞‰πã‰∏∫¬†Â≠óÂΩ¢glyphÔºâ„ÄÇÂ≠óÂΩ¢Â∏∏Áî®‰∫éÈîÆÂÖ•Â∏¶ÊúâÈáçÈü≥ÂíåÂèòÈü≥Á¨¶Âè∑ÁöÑÂ≠óÊØçÔºåÁîüÊàêÊï∞Â≠¶ÂÖ¨ÂºèÊàñËÄÖË¥ßÂ∏Å‰∏≠ÁöÑÁ¨¶Âè∑ÔºåÊàñËÄÖÊ∑ªÂä†ÊúâË∂£ÁöÑË°®ÊÉÖÁ¨¶Âè∑„ÄÇÂú®‰∏Ä‰∫õÂú∞Âå∫ÔºåÊúâ‰∫õÈîÆÁîöËá≥Êúâ‰∏â‰∏™Â≠óÂΩ¢„ÄÇ ÁÑ∂ËÄåÔºå‰∏çËÆ∫‰Ω†Ë∫´Â§Ñ‰ΩïÂ§ÑÔºåÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∫õÂ≠óÂΩ¢‰∏ç‰ºöÂá∫Áé∞Âú®‰Ω†ÁöÑÈîÆÁõò‰∏ä„ÄÇÂπ∏ËøêÁöÑÊòØÔºåLinux Êèê‰æõ‰∫Ü‰ΩøÁî®¬†ÁªÑÂêàÈîÆCompose Key¬†Êù•Ëé∑ÂèñËøô‰∫õÂ≠óÂΩ¢„ÄÇ Âú®‰Ω†ÁöÑÈîÆÁõò‰∏äÊ≤°ÊúâÁªÑÂêàÈîÆËøô‰∏™ÈîÆÔºåËá≥Â∞ëÈªòËÆ§ÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÊ≤°ÊúâÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØ‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ËÆæÂÆö‰∏Ä‰∏™‰Ω†‰∏çÁî®ÁöÑÈîÆ‰Ωú‰∏∫ÁªÑÂêàÈîÆ„ÄÇÊàëÂú®ÁîµËÑë‰∏ä‰ΩøÁî®Á©∫Ê†ºÈîÆÊóÅËæπÁöÑ¬†Alt¬†ÈîÆÔºåËÄåÂú®Âπ≥Êùø‰∏ä‰ΩøÁî®ËèúÂçïÈîÆÔºåÊù•‰Ωú‰∏∫ÁªÑÂêàÈîÆ„ÄÇ ‰∏ãËΩΩ Linux ÁªÑÂêàÈîÆÈÄüÊü•Ë°® Âú® GNOME ‰∏≠ËÆæÁΩÆÁªÑÂêàÈîÆ Âú® GNOME Ê°åÈù¢Ôºå‰ªéËΩØ‰ª∂Â∫ì‰∏≠ÂÆâË£Ö¬†‰ºòÂåñTweaks¬†Â∫îÁî®„ÄÇ‰Ω†‰πüÂèØ‰ª•‰ªéÁªàÁ´ØÂÆâË£ÖÔºàÂü∫‰∫é Debian ÂèëË°åÁâàÁî®¬†apt¬†ÂëΩ‰ª§ÔºåFedora Áî®¬†dnfÔºâÔºö $ sudo dnf install gnome-tweaks ÂêØÂä®‰ºòÂåñÂ∫îÁî®ÂêéÔºö ÂçïÂáªÂ∑¶‰æßÊ†è‰∏≠ÁöÑ¬†ÈîÆÁõòÂíåÈº†Ê†áKeyboard & MouseÁ±ªÂà´ ÊâæÂà∞¬†ÁªÑÂêàÈîÆCompose key¬†ËÆæÁΩÆÂπ∂ÊåáÂÆö‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈîÆ ÂÖ≥Èó≠‰ºòÂåñÂ∫îÁî® Âú® KDE Plasma Ê°åÈù¢ËÆæÁΩÆÁªÑÂêàÈîÆ osition of Compose Key" is checked within that menu, and "Right Alt" is checked within that menu." /> Âú® KDE Plasma Ê°åÈù¢‰∏äÔºåÊâìÂºÄ¬†Á≥ªÁªüËÆæÁΩÆSystem SettingsÔºåÊâæÂà∞¬†ËæìÂÖ•ËÆæÂ§áInput Devices¬†ÊéßÂà∂ÁïåÈù¢„ÄÇÁÑ∂ÂêéÔºö Âú®¬†ËæìÂÖ•ËÆæÂ§áInput Devices¬†ÁïåÈù¢ÔºåÁÇπÂáª ‚ÄúÈ´òÁ∫ßAdvanced‚Äù Ê†áÁ≠æ ÊâæÂà∞¬†ÁªÑÂêàÈîÆ‚Ä¶  ( 2 min )

    Êú¨ÊñáÂ∞ÜÂ∏ÆÂä©‰Ω†ËÆæËÆ°‰∏Ä‰∏™Âü∫‰∫é Web ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÔºå‰ΩøÁî® Node-RED ‰∏∫Âú∞ÈìÅÁ´ôÁöÑÊ±ΩËΩ¶Êèê‰æõ‰∏Ä‰∏™Ëá™Âä®Êô∫ËÉΩÂÅúËΩ¶Á≥ªÁªü„ÄÇ Web Â∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÊòØÂú® Web ÊúçÂä°Âô®‰∏äËøêË°åÁöÑËΩØ‰ª∂„ÄÇÁªàÁ´ØÁî®Êà∑ÈÄöËøá Web ÊµèËßàÂô®ËÆøÈóÆ Web Â∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇWeb Â∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫è‰ΩøÁî®ÂÆ¢Êà∑Á´Ø‚ÄîÊúçÂä°Âô®ÔºàC/SÔºâÊû∂ÊûÑËøõË°åÁºñÁ®ãÔºåËØ•Êû∂ÊûÑÊòØÁî®Êà∑ÔºàÂÆ¢Êà∑Á´ØÔºâÈÄöËøáËøúÁ®ãÊúçÂä°Âô®ÔºàÂèØËÉΩÁî±Á¨¨‰∏âÊñπÊâòÁÆ°ÔºâÊèê‰æõÊúçÂä°„ÄÇWeb APIÔºàÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÁºñÁ®ãÊé•Âè£ÔºâÂú®Êï¥‰∏™ Web ‰∏äÊòØÂèØÁî®ÁöÑÔºåÁî®Êà∑ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøá HTTP ÂçèËÆÆËÆøÈóÆËØ•Êé•Âè£ÔºåÂ¶ÇÂõæ 1 ÊâÄÁ§∫„ÄÇ Êú¨ÊñáÂ∞ÜÊºîÁ§∫Â¶Ç‰Ωï‰∏∫Âú∞ÈìÅËÆæËÆ°‰∏Ä‰∏™Âü∫‰∫é Web ÁöÑÊ±ΩËΩ¶Ëá™Âä®Êô∫ËÉΩÂÅúËΩ¶Á≥ªÁªü„ÄÇ ÂÆÉÊòØ‰ΩøÁî®ÂºÄÊ∫êÁöÑ Node-RED ËÆæËÆ°„ÄÇËØ•Á≥ªÁªü‰ΩøÁî®Ê®°ÊùøËäÇÁÇπÂàõÂª∫‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫§‰∫íÂºèÁöÑ„ÄÅÊó∂Â∞öÁöÑÁî®Êà∑ÁôªÂΩïË°®ÂçïÔºåÁî® HTML Âíå CSS ÁºñÁ†Å‰ª•Ëé∑ÂèñËΩ¶‰∏ªÁöÑËØ¶ÁªÜ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºå‰ªéËÄåÂÆûÁé∞ÂÅúËΩ¶Á≥ªÁªüÁöÑËá™Âä®Âåñ„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®Âõæ 2 ÂíåÂõæ 3 ÁúãÂà∞ÁôªÂΩïË°®ÂçïÂíåÊèê‰∫§Ë°®ÂçïÁöÑÊµÅÁ®ãÂõæ„ÄÇ ‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑËäÇÁÇπÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÔºö Âú∞ÈìÅÊô∫ËÉΩÂÅúËΩ¶ËäÇÁÇπÊµÅÁ®ãËÆæËÆ° Node-RED Áî±¬†node-red¬†ÂëΩ‰ª§ÊøÄÊ¥ª„ÄÇËÆøÈóÆÁΩëÂùÄ¬†http://127.0.0.1:1880/¬†ÂèØ‰ª•ÁúãÂà∞ Node-RED Áî®Êà∑ÁïåÈù¢ÊµÅÁ®ãÊµèËßàÂô®Â∑≤ÁªèÂêØÁî®ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ËÆ§‰∏∫ Node-RED ËÆæÁΩÆÂ∑≤ÂÆåÊàêÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Ê≠£Â∏∏Â∑•‰Ωú‰∫Ü„ÄÇ ÊåâÁÖß‰∏ãÈù¢ÁªôÂá∫ÁöÑÊ≠•È™§ÂàõÂª∫ÁôªÂΩïË°®ÂçïÂíåÊèê‰∫§Ë°®Âçï„ÄÇ ÁôªÂΩïË°®Âçï 1„ÄÅÂú®ËäÇÁÇπÁîªÂ∏É‰∏≠ÔºåÊãñÊîæ¬†http ËæìÂÖ•http in¬†ËäÇÁÇπÔºåËøô‰ºö‰∏∫ÂàõÂª∫ Web ÊúçÂä°ÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ HTTP ËÆøÈóÆÁÇπ„ÄÇ 2„ÄÅÂ∞Ü¬†http ËæìÂÖ•http in¬†ËäÇÁÇπËøûÊé•Âà∞¬†ÂáΩÊï∞function¬†ËäÇÁÇπ„ÄÇÂáΩÊï∞ËäÇÁÇπÊúâÂä©‰∫éÁºñÂÜô JavaScript ÂáΩÊï∞Â§ÑÁêÜËäÇÁÇπÊé•Êî∂Âà∞ÁöÑÊ∂àÊÅØ„ÄÇ 3„ÄÅÂ∞Ü¬†ÂáΩÊï∞function¬†ËäÇÁÇπËøûÊé•Âà∞¬†Ê®°Êùøtemplate¬†ËäÇÁÇπÔºåÊ®°ÊùøËäÇÁÇπÂü∫‰∫éÊèê‰æõÁöÑÊ®°ÊùøÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ Web API„ÄÇ 4„ÄÅÂ∞Ü¬†Ê®°Êùøtemplate¬†ËäÇÁÇπËøûÊé•Âà∞¬†http ‚Ä¶  ( 2 min )

    CoolSpring: ËÉåÊôØÔºö ÊàëÂú®Ëá™Â∑±ÁöÑ hobby project ‰∏≠‰π†ÊÉØ‰ΩøÁî® Tailwind CSS Âíå UnoCSS ÔºåËßâÂæóÂºÄÂèëÊïàÁéáÂæàÈ´òÔºå‰ΩÜÂú®Â∑•‰Ωú‰∏≠ÈúÄË¶ÅÈÅµÂæ™ÁªÑÂÜÖËßÑËåÉ‰ΩøÁî® Sass „ÄÇÈÇ£‰πàÔºåÊúâÊ≤°ÊúâÂèØËÉΩÂÖàÁî®ÂéüÂ≠êÂåñ CSS ÁöÑÂÜôÊ≥ïËøõË°åÂºÄÂèëÔºå‰ΩÜÂú® git commit ÂâçÁî®Â∑•ÂÖ∑ËΩ¨Êç¢Êàê Sass/Less Ôºü ËÆæÊÉ≥ÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÔºö ÂÖàÊääÊ†∑ÂºèÁªüÁªüÂÜôÂú® class ÈáåÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÁî®‰∏Ä‰∏™ CLI Â∑•ÂÖ∑ËΩ¨Êç¢ÔºåÊàñËÄÖÁî®‰∏Ä‰∏™ VSCode Êèí‰ª∂‚ÄúÈáçÊûÑ‚Äù„ÄÇÂæóÂà∞ÁöÑÁªìÊûúÊòØÊ∫êÊñá‰ª∂‰∏≠ JSX ÊàñÊ®°ÁâàÈáåÁöÑÈïø‰∏≤ class ÂêçË¢´ÊõøÊç¢ÊàêÂçï‰∏™ÈöèÊú∫ÂêçÁß∞ÔºàÂêéÁª≠ÊåâÁÖßÂÖ∂Áî®ÈÄî‰∫∫Â∑•ÈáçÂëΩÂêçÔºâÔºåÂπ∂ÁîüÊàê‰∏Ä‰ªΩÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂ∏¶ÂµåÂ•óÂ±ÇÁ∫ßÁöÑ sass/less Êñá‰ª∂„ÄÇ Ê¶ÇÊã¨ÈúÄÊ±ÇÔºö ÊÉ≥‰∏Ä‰∏™Ëã±ÊñáÂÆ£‰º†ËØ≠Â∞±ÊòØÔºöWrite in "Atomic CSS" way, convert to nested CSS before you commit. ÊòØÂê¶Â∑≤ÊúâÊ≠§Á±ªÂûãÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºüÂ¶ÇÊûúÊ≤°ÊúâÔºåÂºÄÂèë‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊúâÊÑè‰πâÂíåÊäÄÊúØ‰∏äÁöÑÂèØËÉΩÊÄßÂêóÔºü Áõ∏‰ºº‰ΩÜ‰∏çÂ§™‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÁöÑÊñπÊ°àÔºö 1. ‰∫ÜËß£Âà∞ Windi CSS Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ Compilation Mode https://windicss.org/posts/modes.html#compilation-mode ÔºåËÉΩÊää‰∏Ä‰∏≤ class ËΩ¨Âåñ‰∏∫ÂΩ¢Â¶Ç‚Äúwindi-15wa4me‚ÄùÁöÑÂçï‰∏™ class ÂêçÔºå‰ΩÜÂÆÉËøô‰∏™Â∫îËØ•ÊòØÂú®ÁºñËØëÊó∂ÁîüÊàêÁöÑ‰∫ßÁâ©‰∏≠Âá∫Áé∞ÔºåËÄåÊàëÂ∏åÊúõÂú®ÂºÄÂèëÊó∂Êèê‰∫§ÁªÑ‰ª∂ÁöÑÊ∫ê‰ª£Á†ÅÂà∞ GitLab ÂâçÂ∞±ÂÅöËΩ¨Êç¢„ÄÇ 2.     Lnz: ÊúÄËøë‰∏∫‰∫ÜÁºìËß£ËÇ©È¢àÔºåÊääÁ¨îËÆ∞Êú¨Áî®ÊîØÊû∂Êû∂‰∫ÜËµ∑Êù•ÔºåÊó•Â∏∏‰ΩøÁî®Â§ñÊé•ÈîÆÁõò ËøõÂÖ•‰∏Ä‰∫õÁΩëÁ´ôÈúÄË¶ÅËá™Âä®Â°´ÂÖÖÂØÜÁ†ÅÊó∂ÔºåÈúÄË¶Å Touch ID ËÆ§ËØÅÔºåËøôÊó∂ÈúÄË¶ÅÊääÊâãÊä¨Ëµ∑Êù•ÂéªÂ§üÊàëÊû∂ÁöÑÊØîËæÉÈ´òÁöÑÁ¨îËÆ∞Êú¨ÁöÑ power ÈîÆÔºåËÄåËøõÂÖ•Á≥ªÁªüËÆæÁΩÆÁöÑ passwords È°µÈù¢Êó∂ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®ÊâãË°®ÂèåÂáªËøõË°åËÆ§ËØÅÔºåËØ∑ÈóÆÊòØÂê¶ÊúâÂäûÊ≥ïËÆæÁΩÆÂú®ÁΩëÈ°µËá™Âä®Â°´ÂÖÖÂØÜÁ†ÅÊó∂‰πü‰ΩøÁî®ÊâãË°®ËøõË°åÂèåÂáªËÆ§ËØÅ  ( 1 min )

    CKA & CKAD Series (Part2): Replication controller & replicaset
    Assume that we had a single POD running our application. What if for some reason, our application crashes and the POD fails? Users will no longer be able to access our application. o prevent users from losing access to our application, we So does that mean you can‚Äôt use a replication controller if you plan to have a single POD? No! Even if you have a single POD, the replication controller can help by automatically bringing up a new POD when the existing one fails. Thus the replication controller ensures that the specified number of PODs are running at all times. Even if it‚Äôs just 1 or 100. Another reason we need replication controller is to create multiple PODs to share the load across them. For example, in this simple scenario we have a single POD serving a set of users. ‚Ä¶  ( 8 min )

Note: you can use git status to see all open changes Take the file name of the file you want to revert and execute the following command. git checkout filename.extension This command will revert the file to what it used to be.     Test-Driven Development with Python
    Test-driven development (TDD) is an established technique for delivering better software more rapidly and sustainably over time. It is a standard practice in software engineering. In this blog, I'll be explaining about test-driven development (TDD) and a how-to guide to TDD with python. In case you didn't even hear about it, also tag along. Test-driven development (TDD) is a software development process relying on software requirements being converted to test cases before software is fully developed, and tracking all software development by repeatedly testing the software against all test cases. In short, It is when you write tests before you write the code that's being tested. It has number of benefits Improved design of the system Better code quality and flexibility Good documentation as‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )

    Bugs: a blessing and a curse
    Intro. Curse. Blessing. Lesson. Bugs can be a lesson and a curse so how do we manage them, one way I learned when I attended havards cs50 computer science course is by speaking to a rubber duck, ok not necessarily a rubber duck but speak to something or someone-if they understand what you're saying- explain your step by step approach to the program and what you wrote, chances are you'll find the error you're looking for or where you went wrong and you can solve it or google it. Also feel free to take breaks when debugging your codes, something as simple as taking walks, playing with your pet, or going out with someone can clear your head and when you come back, you'll be ready to squash that bug. Thanks for reading, hope it helps, like and comment on ways you cool off to debug your codes.  ( 5 min )
    Javascript cheat sheet: .slice() and .splice()
    I recently came across a twitter post where the user challenged others if they knew the difference between the js methods .slice() and .splice() without googling them. A lot of people mixed them up. So I've created this simplified cheat sheet of everything you need to know about the 2 methods. .slice() and splice() are both array methods. both of them return arrays as outputs the key is to pay attention the what they return as the output array and if they mutate the original array (they one on which the were applied to) .slice() returns selected elements in an array, as a new array. Selection is done by index. .slice() does not affect the original array With splice() you can select one or more elements. For example: This code snippet returns 3 (which is at index 2) [1,2,3,4,5].slice(2) // returns 3 (which is at index 2) and this code snippet returns 2,3,4 (from index 1 to 4 exclusively) [1,2,3,4,5].slice(1,4) // returns 2,3,4 (from index 1 to 4 exclusively) .splice modifies the original array (adds and/or removes elements from the array) The method returns the original array **modified** With splice you can: remove elements [1,2,3,4,5].splice(3) // returns [1,2,3] (first 3 elements) [1,2,3,4,5].splice(2,2) // at position 2 remove 2 elements (returns [1,2,5]) add elements [1,2,5].splice(2,0,3,4) // at postion 2 add 2 elements (returns [1,2,3,4,5]) remove and add elements at the same time // at position 2, remove 1 elements and add 2 new items [1,2,3,4,5].splice(2,2,"HTML","CSS") // returns [1,2,"HTML","CSS",5] Remember: .splice() mutates the array, .slice() does not! Hope this is helpful to someone üíú  ( 4 min )

    testcaoy7: ÊúÄËøëÊï¥ÁêÜ‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏ãÁîµËÑëÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÂºÄÂßãÊï¥Â§á‰ªΩ„ÄÇ Â§á‰ªΩÁöÑËØùÔºåË≤å‰ººÊúÄÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑÂäûÊ≥ïÊòØ‰π∞Âá†‰∏™ÁßªÂä®Á°¨ÁõòÔºüÊú∫Ê¢∞ÁßªÂä®Á°¨Áõò‰ΩìË¥®‰∏ÄËà¨Ëà¨ÔºåÂ∞±ÊÄïÊëî‰∏Ä‰∏ãÔºåÊàñËÄÖÈÅáÂà∞ÂìÅÊéß‰∏çÂ•ΩÁöÑÁ°¨ÁõòÔºåÂèçÊ≠£ÊÄªËßâÂæó‰∏çÊòØÂæàÁâ¢Èù†„ÄÇSSD Êõ¥‰∏çÊâìÁÆóËÄÉËôëÔºåÊï¥ÁêÜÂá∫Êù•ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÈáèÂ§ßÁ∫¶ 10T ‰∏çÂà∞Ôºå‰π∞Â§öÂùóÂ§ßÂÆπÈáèÁöÑ SSD ËøòÊòØÊØîËæÉË¥µÁöÑ„ÄÇ ÁÑ∂ÂêéÂºÄÂßãËÄÉËôë‰π∞‰∏™ NAS ÔºåÂÖ∂ÂÆûÊàëÂ∑≤ÁªèËÄÉËôëÂæà‰πÖ‰∫ÜÔºåÁªÑË£ÖÊú∫„ÄÅÂìÅÁâåÊú∫ÁöÑÊñπÊ°àÈÉΩËÄÉËôëËøáÔºå‰ΩÜÊúÄÂêéËøòÊòØÊ≤°ÊúâÈÄâÊã©„ÄÇ‰∏ªË¶ÅÊòØ NAS Êèê‰æõÁöÑÂêÑÁßçÂäüËÉΩÊàëÂπ∂‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÔºåÊàë‰∏çË∑ëËôöÊãüÊú∫„ÄÅDocker Ôºå‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÂ±ÄÂüüÁΩë‰∏≤ÊµÅÂ§öÂ™í‰ΩìÔºåÊàëÂè™Ë¶Å‰∏™Áâ¢Èù†ÁöÑÂú∞ÊñπÂ§ö‰øùÂ≠ò‰∏Ä‰ªΩÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÂâØÊú¨„ÄÇ ÊúÄÂêéËä±Èí±‰π∞‰∫ÜÁ£ÅÂ∏¶Ôºà LTO-5 ÔºâÔºå‰æøÂÆúÊòØÁúü‰æøÂÆúÔºåÊú∫ÊàøÊ∑òÊ±∞ÁöÑÊú∫Âô® 1K ÔºàÂÖçË¥πËµ†ÈÄÅ HBA Âç°ÔºâÔºå‰∫åÊâãÁ£ÅÂ∏¶ 30 Âùó‰∏ÄÂç∑ÔºåLTO-5 Á£ÅÂ∏¶ÁöÑÈùûÂéãÁº©ÂÆπÈáèÊòØ 1.5TB Ôºå10 ÁõòÁ£ÅÂ∏¶Â¶ÇÊûúÂÆåÂÖ®‰∏çÂéãÁº©ÁöÑËØùÂèØ‰ª•Ë£Ö 15T ÔºåÊâç 300 ÂùóÈí±ÔºåÊØîÂæàÂ§ö Switch Ê∏∏ÊàèÂç°Â∏¶Ëøò‰æøÂÆú‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ ‰∏ÄÂÆ∂Âæ∑‰ºÅËøòÊèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÂÖçË¥πÁöÑÁ£ÅÂ∏¶Â§á‰ªΩËΩØ‰ª∂ÔºåÊèê‰æõ‰∏Ä‰∫õËØ∏Â¶ÇÊñá‰ª∂ÊµèËßà„ÄÅÊñá‰ª∂ÊâìÂåÖ„ÄÅÂ¢ûÈáèÂ§á‰ªΩ‰πãÁ±ªÁöÑÂü∫Êú¨ÂäüËÉΩÔºå‰∏™‰∫∫Áî®Áî®Ë∂≥Â§ü‰∫Ü Á£ÅÂ∏¶ÂÜôÂ•ΩÂêéÊâîÁÆ±Â≠êÈáåÂ°ûÊ≤ôÂèëÂ∫ï‰∏ã‰∫ÜÔºåÂ¢ûÈáèÂ§á‰ªΩÁöÑËØùÔºåÁõÆÊµãÂçäÂπ¥Êêû‰∏ÄÊ¨°Â∞±Ë°å‰∫ÜÔºåÂîØ‰∏ÄÁæé‰∏≠‰∏çË∂≥ÁöÑÊòØÔºåLTO-5 ÂÆπÈáèËøòÊòØÂ∞è‰∫ÜÁÇπÔºàÊú¨ÊÉ≥‰∏ä LTO-6 ÁöÑÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØ LTO-6 Êú∫Âô®Ë¥µ‰∫Ü‰∏çÂ∞ëÔºâÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÊØèÂπ¥Ë¶ÅÂÄíÂ∏¶‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÔºåÊääÁ£ÅÂ∏¶Âç∑Á¥ßÔºåÁÆóÊòØÁª¥Êä§Âêß„ÄÇ  ( 2 min )

    Syntax Highlight ‚Äì ‰∏∫ macOS Âø´ÈÄüÊü•ÁúãÊ∑ªÂä†‰ª£Á†ÅÈ´ò‰∫ÆÂäüËÉΩÔºåÊîØÊåÅ 100+ Ê†ºÂºè
    Syntax Highlight ÊòØ‰∏ÄÊ¨æÂèØ‰ª•‰∏∫ macOS Âø´ÈÄüÊü•ÁúãÊ∑ªÂä†‰ª£Á†ÅÈ´ò‰∫ÆÂäüËÉΩÁöÑÂ∞èÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåÊîØÊåÅË∂ÖËøá 100 ÁßçÊ†ºÂºèÔºåÂè™ÈúÄË¶ÅÂØπÁùÄÊñá‰ª∂Êåâ‰∏ãÁ©∫Ê†ºÔºåÂç≥ÂèØÂø´ÈÄüÈ¢ÑËßàÈ´ò‰∫Æ‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÇ@Appinn Âú®ÂâçÂá†Â§©ÁöÑÂè¶Â§ñ‰∏Ä‰∏™  ( 6 min )

    Windows Á≥ªÁªüËá™Â∏¶ÁöÑÊ°åÈù¢ÁúãËÖª‰∫ÜÔºåÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÊç¢‰∏™È£éÊ†ºÊç¢‰∏™ÂøÉÊÉÖÔºüÊàñÊòØÊúüÂæÖÂú®ÁîµËÑë‰∏ä‰πüÁî®‰∏äÂêÑÁßçÊ°åÈù¢Â∞èÁªÑ‰ª∂Ôºü ÂÖºÂÖ∑È¢úÂÄº‰∏éÂÆûÁî®ÁöÑ BitDock Âø´ÂéªËØïËØïÔºåËøôÊ¨æ Windows Ê°åÈù¢ÁæéÂåñÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåËÆ©‰Ω†Ëá™Áî±ÂÆö‰πâÂñúÊ¨¢ÁöÑÊ°å  ( 6 min )

    Á°¨Ê†∏ËßÇÂØü #713 ÈáèÂ≠êËÆ°ÁÆóÂú® 6 ÂàÜÈíüÂÜÖËß£ÂÜ≥‰∫Ü 3854 ‰∏™ÂèòÈáèÁöÑÂÆùÈ©¨‰ºòÂåñÈóÆÈ¢ò
    ÈáèÂ≠êËÆ°ÁÆóÂú® 6 ÂàÜÈíüÂÜÖËß£ÂÜ≥‰∫Ü 3854 ‰∏™ÂèòÈáèÁöÑÂÆùÈ©¨‰ºòÂåñÈóÆÈ¢ò Âú®Ê±ΩËΩ¶Â∞§ÂÖ∂ÊòØËá™Âä®È©æÈ©∂Ê±ΩËΩ¶‰∏äÂÆâÊîæ‰º†ÊÑüÂô®Ê∂âÂèäÂ§ßÈáèÁöÑÂèòÈáèÔºåÂ¶ÇÂ∫ïÁõòËÆæËÆ°ÔºåÊúâÊ≤°ÊúâÈöúÁ¢çÁâ©Ôºà‰∏çÂêå‰ΩçÁΩÆÊèê‰æõ‰∫Ü‰∏çÂêåËßÜÈáéÔºâÔºåÈ£éÈòªÂíåÈáçÈáèÂπ≥Ë°°Á≠âÁ≠âÔºåËøôÈúÄË¶ÅÂ§ßÈáèÁöÑËØïÈîôÔºå‰∏çÂêåÁöÑËΩ¶ÂûãËøòÈúÄË¶ÅÈáçÊñ∞Âà∂ÂÆö‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÊñπÊ°à„ÄÇÂÆùÈ©¨Ê±ΩËΩ¶ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÊ∂âÂèäÂà∞‰∫Ü 3854 ‰∏™ÂèòÈáèÂíå 500 ‰∏™Á∫¶ÊùüÊù°‰ª∂ÔºåÁªèÂÖ∏ËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫Ëß£ÂÜ≥Ëøô‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢òÈúÄË¶ÅÂ§ßÈáèÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥„ÄÇÈáèÂ≠êËÆ°ÁÆóÂÖ¨Âè∏ QCI ‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑÊòØÂÖ∂Êñ∞ÈáèÂ≠êÁ°¨‰ª∂ÔºåÂú® 6 ÂàÜÈíüÂÜÖËß£ÂÜ≥‰∫ÜËØ•ÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÊèê‰æõ‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Áî± 15 ‰∏™‰º†ÊÑüÂô®ÊûÑÊàêÁöÑÊñπÊ°à„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöTom's Hardware ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöÂ±ÖÁÑ∂ÂèØ‰ª•Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÊüêÁßçÂÖ∑‰ΩìÈóÆÈ¢ò‰∫ÜÔºüÈÇ£ËØ¥ÊòéÈáèÂ≠êËÆ°ÁÆóÊ≠•ÂÖ•ÂÆûÁî®Êõ¥Ëøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•‰∫Ü„ÄÇ ‰∫öÈ©¨ÈÄäÂ∞ÜÂÖ≥Èó≠ÂÖ∂ÁΩëÁõòÂ≠òÂÇ®ÊúçÂä° ‰∫öÈ©¨ÈÄäÂë®‰∫îÊó©‰∏äÂèëÈÄÅÁîµÂ≠êÈÇÆ‰ª∂ÈÄöÁü•Áî®Êà∑ÔºåÂ∞Ü‰∫é 2023 Âπ¥ 12 Êúà 31 Êó•ÂÖ≥Èó≠ÂÖ∂Â∑≤ËøêËê• 11 Âπ¥ÁöÑÁΩëÁõòÂ≠òÂÇ®ÊúçÂä°Ôºå‰ª•Êõ¥ÂÖÖÂàÜÂú∞Â∞ÜÁ≤æÂäõÈõÜ‰∏≠Âú®‚Äú‰∫öÈ©¨ÈÄäÁÖßÁâá‚Äù‰∏ä„ÄÇ‰∫öÈ©¨ÈÄäË°®Á§∫ÔºåÁî®Êà∑Â∏êÊà∑‰∏≠ÁöÑÁÖßÁâáÂíåËßÜÈ¢ëÂ∑≤Ëá™Âä®‰øùÂ≠òÂà∞‰∫öÈ©¨ÈÄäÁÖßÁâá‰∏≠„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†‰æùÈù†ËØ•ÊúçÂä°ËøõË°åÊñá‰ª∂Â≠òÂÇ®ÔºåÂàôÈúÄË¶ÅÂú®ÁªìÊùüÊúçÂä°Êó•Êúü‰πãÂâçËÆøÈóÆÂπ∂‰∏ãËΩΩÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöGeek Wire ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöÁúãÊù•ÁΩëÁõòÊúçÂä°ÁõàÂà©ÂâçÊôØÂ†™ÂøßÂïäÔºåÊúâËøô‰∏™È£éÂêëÊ†áÔºåÂõΩÂÜÖÁöÑÁΩëÁõòÊúçÂä°‰ºöÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂë¢Ôºü QEMU 7.1 Â∞ÜÂ∏¶Êù•ÈæôËäØÊû∂ÊûÑÊîØÊåÅ QEMU 7.1-rc0 Â∑≤ÁªèÂèëÂ∏ÉÔºåÂÖ∂Á®≥ÂÆöÁâàÊú¨Â∞ÜÂú®Âá†Âë®ÂêéÂèëÂ∏É„ÄÇQEMU 7.1 Â∞ÜÂàùÂßãÊîØÊåÅ 64 ‰ΩçÈæôËäØÊû∂ÊûÑÁöÑ 3A5000 Á≥ªÂàó SoC„ÄÇQEMU 7.1 ‰πüÂ∞ÜÊîØÊåÅÊõ¥Â§öÁöÑ RISC-V ÁâπÊÄßÔºåÂ¶Ç RISC-V ÁâπÊùÉËßÑÊ†º 1.12 ÁâàÔºåÊîπËøõÁöÑ PMU ÂÆûÁé∞ÔºåZmmul Êâ©Â±ïÁ≠â„ÄÇÂØπ‰∫é QEMU ËøÅÁßªÔºåÂÆÉÁé∞Âú®ÊîØÊåÅ Linux ‰∏äÁöÑÈõ∂Êã∑Ë¥ùÂèëÈÄÅÔºå‰ª•ÂáèÂ∞ëÊ∫ê‰∏ªÊú∫‰∏äÁöÑ CPU ‰ΩøÁî®Áéá„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöPhoronix ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöÈæôËäØ‰∏çÊñ≠Âú∞Â∞ÜÂêÑÁßçÈ©±Âä®Êèê‰∫§Âà∞‰∏äÊ∏∏ÔºåÂèØËßÅÂÖ∂ÂèëÂ±ïÈÄüÂ∫¶Âú®Âä†Âø´„ÄÇ  ( 2 min )

    Êê∫ÊâãÂàõ‰ΩúÔºåÂÖ±ÂêåÊàêÈïøÔºÅËøôÊòØÊàëÂèÇ‰∏é„ÄåÊéòÈáëÊó•Êñ∞ËÆ°Âàí ¬∑ 8 ÊúàÊõ¥ÊñáÊåëÊàò„ÄçÁöÑÁ¨¨4Â§©ÔºåÁÇπÂáªÊü•ÁúãÊ¥ªÂä®ËØ¶ÊÉÖ ËÆ∞ÂΩï Flutter ÂºÄÂèëËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÈÅáÂà∞ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∫õÈóÆÈ¢òÂíåÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÔΩû 1. --no-sound-null-safety ÈîôËØØ on vscode ‰∏äÈù¢ÊòØ VSCode ÁºñËæëÂô®‰∏≠Á©∫Ê†°È™åÈîôËØØ„ÄÇËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÔºö // vscode ÁºñËæëÂô®È°πÁõÆÊ†πÁõÆÂΩï‰∏≠ÂàõÂª∫Êñá‰ª∂ .vscode/launch.json // Ê∑ªÂä†ÂÜÖÂÆπ "args": [ "--no-sound-null-safety" ] // ÂÆåÊï¥ÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂‰ª£Á†ÅÁ§∫‰æã { "configurations":[ { "name": "jimmy flutter demo", "program": "lib/main.dart", "request": "launch", "type": "dart", "args": [ "--no-sound-null-safety" ] } ] } // ‰πãÂêéÈáçÊñ∞ËøêË°åÈ°πÁõÆÂç≥ÂèØ 2.     FlutterÂÆûÁé∞ÂæÆ‰ø°ÊúãÂèãÂúàÈ´òÊñØÊ®°Á≥äÊïàÊûú

ÂÆûË∑µ Âú®Flutter‰æßÂÆûÁé∞È´òÊñØÊ®°Á≥äÊØîËæÉÁÆÄÂçïÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Áõ¥Êé•‰ΩøÁî®Á≥ªÁªüÁöÑBackdropFilterÂáΩÊï∞ÂÆûÁé∞ÔºåÈúÄË¶Å‰º†ÂÖ•‰∏Ä‰∏™filterÊñπÂºèÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÂØπchildÂå∫ÂüüËøõË°åÊ®°Á≥äËøáÊª§Ôºõ const BackdropFilter({ Key? key, required this.filter, Widget? child, this.blendMode = BlendMode.srcOver, }) : assert(filter != null), super(key: key, child: child); FlutterÊèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÁÆÄÂåñImageFilteredÂÆûÁé∞È´òÊñØÊ®°Á≥äÔºå‰ª£Á†ÅÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÔºö ImageFiltered( imageFilter: ImageFilter.blur(sigmaX: 20, sigmaY: 20), child: Image.network(url,fit: BoxFit.cover, height: expandedHeight, width: width), ), ÈÄöËøáÊ≠§ÊñπÂºèÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÈùûÂ∏∏ÁÆÄÁ∫¶ÂÆûÁé∞ÂÖ®Â±èÈ´òÊñØÊ®°Á≥äÔΩûÔºåÁé∞Âú®ÈöæÁÇπÊòØ‰∏ä‰∏ãËæπÁïåÂå∫ÂüüÁöÑËæπÁïåÊ®°Á≥äÂ§ÑÁêÜÔºåËøôÈáåÈúÄË¶Å‰ΩøÁî®‰∏Ä‰∏™ShaderMaskÁªÑ‰ª∂ÔºåÂú®Flutter‰æßShaderMask‰∏ªË¶ÅÊòØÂÆûÁé∞Ê∏êÂèòËøáÊ∏°ËÉΩÂäõÁöÑÔºõ const ShaderMas‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )

  • Open

    ‰øÆÂ§ç Ubuntu Linux ‰∏≠ ‚ÄúCommand ‚Äòpython‚Äô not found‚Äù ÁöÑÈîôËØØ
    Â¶Ç‰ΩïÂú® Linux ÁªàÁ´Ø‰∏≠ËøêË°å‰∏Ä‰∏™ Python Á®ãÂ∫èÔºüÂÉèËøôÊ†∑ÔºåÂØπÂêóÔºü python program.py ÁÑ∂ËÄåÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ËØïÂõæÂú® UbuntuÔºàÂíåÂÖ∂‰ªñ‰∏Ä‰∫õÂèëË°åÁâàÔºâ‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®¬†python¬†ÂëΩ‰ª§ÔºåÂÆÉ‰ºöÊäõÂá∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈîôËØØ„ÄÇ command ‚Äòpython‚Äô not found, did you mean: command ‚Äòpython3‚Äô from deb python3 command ‚Äòpython‚Äô from deb python-is-python3 Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†Ê≥®ÊÑèËøô‰∏™ÈîôËØØ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºåÂÆÉËØ¥Êòé‰∫ÜÂæàÂ§ö‰∏úË•ø„ÄÇËøôÈáåÁöÑ¬†python¬†ÂëΩ‰ª§ÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÊòØ¬†python3„ÄÇ Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†‰∏çÁêÜËß£Ôºå‰∏çÁî®ÊãÖÂøÉ„ÄÇÊàëÂ∞ÜÂú®ËøôÈáåËØ¶ÁªÜËß£Èáä„ÄÇ ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÂú® Ubuntu ‰∏äÊ≤°ÊúâÂèëÁé∞ python ÂëΩ‰ª§Ôºü ËøôÊòØÂõ†‰∏∫ Python ËØ≠Ë®Ä‰∏çÊòØ‰ª•¬†python¬†ÁöÑÂΩ¢ÂºèÂÆâË£ÖÁöÑÔºåËÄåÊòØ‰ª•¬†python3¬†Êàñ¬†python2¬†ÁöÑÂΩ¢ÂºèÂÆâË£ÖÁöÑÔºàÂú®‰∏Ä‰∫õËÄÅÁöÑ Ubuntu ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Ôºâ„ÄÇ Âú®ÈÅ•ËøúÁöÑËøáÂéªÁöÑÊüê‰∏™Êó∂Èó¥ÁÇπÔºåPython ÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÊòØ‰Ωú‰∏∫¬†python¬†ÂåÖ/ÂèØÊâßË°åÊñá‰ª∂Êèê‰æõÁöÑ„ÄÇÂΩì Python ÂèëÂ∏ÉÁ¨¨‰∫åÁâàÊó∂ÔºåUbuntu ÂíåÂÖ∂‰ªñÂèëË°åÁâà‰∏çÂæó‰∏çÂêåÊó∂ÊîØÊåÅ Python 1.x Âíå 2.x ÁâàÊú¨„ÄÇ Âõ†Ê≠§Ôºå‰ªñ‰ª¨Â∞ÜËæÉÊñ∞ÁöÑ Python ÁâàÊú¨ÂëΩÂêç‰∏∫¬†python2Ôºå‰ª•Âå∫ÂàÜËøô‰∏§‰∏™ÁâàÊú¨„ÄÇÂÖ∂‰ªñÂ∫îÁî®ÊàñÂ∫ì‰πüÂú®ÂÖ∂‰ª£Á†Å‰∏≠ÊåáÂÆö¬†python¬†Êàñ¬†python2„ÄÇ ÊúÄÁªàÔºåPython 1 ÁâàÊú¨Ë¢´ÂÆåÂÖ®ÂÅúÁî®Ôºå‰ΩÜËΩØ‰ª∂ÂåÖÁªßÁª≠Ë¢´ÂëΩÂêç‰∏∫¬†python2„ÄÇ Á±ª‰ººÂú∞ÔºåÂΩì Python 3 ÁâàÊú¨ÂèëÂ∏ÉÊó∂ÔºåÂèëË°åÁâàÂºÄÂßãÂêåÊó∂Êèê‰æõ¬†python2¬†Âíå¬†python3¬†ÂåÖ„ÄÇ Python 2 ‰∏çÂÜçË¢´ÊîØÊåÅÔºåPython 3.x ÊòØ‰Ω†Âú® Ubuntu ‰∏äÂÆâË£ÖÁöÑÁâàÊú¨„ÄÇËØ•ËΩØ‰ª∂ÂåÖ‰ªçË¢´ÂëΩÂêç‰∏∫¬†python3„ÄÇ ÊÄªÁªì‰∏Ä‰∏ãÔºå‰Ω†Â∑≤ÁªèÂú® Ubuntu ‰∏äÂÆâË£Ö‰∫Ü Python„ÄÇÂÆÉÊòØ‰ª•‚Ä¶  ( 2 min )
    ÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫Á¨¨‰∫åÂ±äÁêÜ‰∫ãÂ§ß‰ºöÂúÜÊª°Âè¨ÂºÄÔºÅËÄÅÁéãÂ∫îÈÇÄ‰Ωú‰∏∫ÁâπÁ∫¶È°æÈóÆÂä†ÂÖ•
    2022 Âπ¥ 7 Êúà 26 Êó•ÔºåÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫ÔºàOpenAnolisÔºâ‰∫éÂåó‰∫¨È°∫Âà©Âè¨ÂºÄÁ¨¨‰∫åÂ±äÁêÜ‰∫ãÂ§ß‰ºöÔºåÊù•Ëá™ÈòøÈáå‰∫ë„ÄÅÁªü‰ø°ËΩØ‰ª∂„ÄÅËÅîÈÄö„ÄÅÁîµ‰ø°‰∫ë„ÄÅÁßªÂä®‰∫ë„ÄÅÈæôËäØ„ÄÅÂÖÜËäØ„ÄÅIntel„ÄÅArm Á≠â17ÂÆ∂ÁêÜ‰∫ãÂçï‰ΩçÁöÑÁêÜ‰∫ã‰ª£Ë°®Âá∫Â∏≠„ÄÇÊú¨Ê¨°‰ºöËÆÆÁî±ÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫ËøêËê•ÂßîÂëò‰ºö‰∏ªÂ∏≠ÈôàÁª™‰∏ªÊåÅÔºåÂ§ß‰ºö‰∏ªË¶ÅÂÜÖÂÆπÊúâÔºöÊäÄÊúØÂ∑•‰Ωú‰∏éËøêËê•Â∑•‰ΩúÊ±áÊä•„ÄÅÁêÜ‰∫ãÊç¢Â±äÈÄâ‰∏æ„ÄÅÁ§æÂå∫ÊúÄÊñ∞Á´†Á®ãË°®ÂÜ≥„ÄÅÈ°æÈóÆËÅòËØ∑ÂíåÊéàÁâå‰ª™ÂºèÁ≠â„ÄÇÁêÜ‰∫ã‰ª¨ÂØπÁ§æÂå∫ÂΩìÂâçÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÂùáÁªô‰∫à‰∫ÜÂÖÖÂàÜËÇØÂÆöÔºå‰πüÂØπÁ§æÂå∫Êú™Êù•ÁöÑÂèëÂ±ïÊèêÂá∫‰∫ÜÂàáÂÆûÊúâÊïàÁöÑÂª∫ËÆÆ„ÄÇ ÔºàÂõæ/ÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫Êñ∞‰∏ÄÂ±äÂÖ®‰ΩìÁêÜ‰∫ãÂêàÂΩ±Ôºâ¬† ‰ºöËÆÆÂºÄÂú∫ÔºåÁî±ÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫ÁêÜ‰∫ãÈïøÈ©¨Ê∂õÂèëË®ÄÔºö‚ÄúÈ¶ñÂÖàÊÑüË∞¢ÂêÑ‰ΩçÔºå‰ªäÂπ¥Áñ´ÊÉÖÂèçÂèçÂ§çÂ§çÔºåÊ≠§Ê¨°Êàë‰ª¨ËÉΩÂ§üÈΩêËÅö‰∏ÄÂ†ÇÁúüÁöÑÂæà‰∏çÂÆπÊòì„ÄÇËøáÂéª‰∏ÄÂπ¥ËôΩÁÑ∂ÁªèÂéÜ‰∫ÜÂæàÂ§öÈ£éÈõ®ÂíåÂùéÂù∑Ôºå‰ΩÜÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫ÂèñÂæóÁöÑÊàêÁª©ËøòÊòØÂèØÂúàÂèØÁÇπÁöÑÔºÅÂéªÂπ¥Ëøô‰∏™Êó∂Èó¥ÁÇπÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂùêÂú®‰∏ÄËµ∑‰∏∫Á§æÂå∫Âà∂ÂÆö‰∫ÜËØ¶ÁªÜÁöÑËßÑÁ´†Âà∂Â∫¶ÔºåÁªèÂéÜ‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÂπ¥ÁöÑËøê‰ΩúÔºå‰πü‰∏ÄÂÆöÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∫õÊñ∞ÁöÑÊÉ≥Ê≥ï‰∫ßÁîüÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Âú®ËÅöÁÑ¶ÂΩì‰∏ãÁöÑÂêåÊó∂‰πüÂ∫îËØ•ÈÅ•ÊÉ≥Êú™Êù•ËØ•ÂÅöÁÇπ‰ªÄ‰πàÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÊòØÂê¶ÊúâÊñ∞ÁöÑÁõÆÊ†á‰ΩøÂëΩÂíåÊÑøÊôØ„ÄÇ ÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫ÂâØÁêÜ‰∫ãÈïøÂº†Á£ä‰πüÂº∫Ë∞É‰∫ÜÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫Â∞ÜÂêÑÂÆ∂ËÅöÈõÜÂú®‰∏ÄËµ∑ÁöÑÊÑè‰πâ„ÄÇ‰ªñËØ¥ÈÅìÔºö‚ÄúÊúÄËøë‰∏ÄÂπ¥ÂÖÖÊª°‰∫ÜÂêÑÁßç‰∏çÁ°ÆÂÆöÊÄßÔºå‰∏çËÆ∫ÊòØÁñ´ÊÉÖËøòÊòØÂêÑË°å‰∏öÂèëÂ±ï„ÄÅÊäÄÊúØÂèëÂ±ï‰ª•ÂèäÈæôËú•ÂºÄÊ∫êÊìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªüÁ§æÂå∫„ÄÇ‰∏™‰∫∫ËßâÂæóÊúâÂè•ËØùÂØπ‰∫éÊâÄÊúâÂ∏åÊúõÊàêÂäüÁöÑÁ§æÂå∫ÂæàÈÄÇÁî®Ôºö‰∏Ä‰∫∫Ë°åÂø´Ôºå‰ºó‰∫∫Ë°åËøú„ÄÇÊàëÂ∏åÊúõÁ§æÂå∫Êú™Êù•Âú®ÊäÄÊúØ„ÄÅÁêÜËÆ∫ÂíåËøêËê•Á≠âÂ±ÇÈù¢ÁªßÁª≠ÂÅöÂá∫Êõ¥Â§ßÁöÑÊàêÁª©ÔºåËÆ©Êàë‰ª¨ÁöÑÁ§æÂå∫‰ª•ÂèäÁ§æÂå∫‰ª£Ë°®ÁöÑÂêÑ‰∏™‰∫ß‰∏öÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ÈÉΩËÉΩÊúâÊõ¥È´òÂ±ÇÊ¨°ÁöÑËøõÂ±ï„ÄÇ‚Äù Êé•‰∏ãÊù•ÔºåÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫ËøéÊù•Êñ∞‰∏ÄÂ±äÊç¢Â±äÈÄâ‰∏æ„ÄÇ‰ºö‰∏äÔºåÁêÜ‰∫ãÈïøÂíåÂâØÁêÜ‰∫ãÈïøÂàÜÂà´ËøõË°åÈÄâ‰∏æÊºîËÆ≤‰∏éÂ∑•‰ΩúÊÄªÁªìÔºåÂêÑ‰ΩçÁêÜ‰∫ã‰ª£Ë°®‰∏æÊâãË°®ÂÜ≥ÔºåÊúÄÁªàÂÖ®Á•®ÈÄöËøáÔºåË°®ÂÜ≥ÁîüÊïà„ÄÇÈ©¨Ê∂õÁªßÁª≠ÊãÖ‰ªªÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫ÁêÜ‰∫ãÈïøÔºåÂº†Á£äÁªßÁª≠ÊãÖ‰ªªÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫ÂâØÁêÜ‰∫ãÈïøÔºåÂÖ∂‰ªñÁêÜ‰∫ãÊàêÂëòÊó†ÂèòÂä®„ÄÇ ÔºàÂõæ/ÁêÜ‰∫ãÂ§ß‰ºöÁé∞Âú∫‰∏æÊâãË°®ÂÜ≥Ôºâ Êç¢Â±äÈÄâ‰∏æËøáÂêéÔºåÁî±ÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫ËøêËê•ÂßîÂëò‰ºöÂâØ‰∏ªÂ∏≠‰ªªÁ¥´‰∏úËøõË°åÁ§æÂå∫ËøêËê•Ê±áÊä•ÔºåÂ∞±Á§æÂå∫ËøêËê•ËøõÂ±ïÂíåÊú™Êù•ËøêËê•ËÆ°ÂàíÂêëÁé∞Âú∫ÁêÜ‰∫ã‰ª£Ë°®‰ª¨ÂÅöÂá∫ÈòêËø∞„ÄÇ Ëøë‰∏ÄÂπ¥ÔºåÈæôËú•Á§æÂå∫Â∑≤ÈôÜÁª≠ÂèëÂ∏É‰∫Ü¬†Ano‚Ä¶  ( 2 min )
    ÊòØÊó∂ÂÄôÊäõÂºÉ 32 ‰ΩçÁöÑ LinuxÔºåÊîπÁî® 64 ‰ΩçÁöÑ‰∫Ü
    Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÊÉ≥Ëé∑ÂæóÂÆâÂÖ®ÁöÑ‰ΩìÈ™åÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØËÉΩ‰∏ç‰ºöÂÜçÁªßÁª≠‰ΩøÁî® 32 ‰Ωç Linux ÂÜÖÊ†∏„ÄÇ Êàë‰ª¨ÊúâÂæàÂ§ö¬†‰∏∫ 32 ‰ΩçÁ≥ªÁªüÂÆöÂà∂ÁöÑ Linux ÂèëË°åÁâà„ÄÇ ÈÇ£‰πàÔºå‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÊàëÊÉ≥Ë¶Å‰∏çÈºìÂä±‰ΩøÁî® Ê≤°ÈîôÔºå‰∏éÂÖ∂‰ªñÊìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªü‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÊòØÔºåLinux ÂèëË°åÁâàÂÖÅËÆ∏‰Ω†ÈáçÊñ∞Âà©Áî®ÊóßÁ°¨‰ª∂„ÄÇ ‰Ω†ËÉΩÂ§üÂ∞Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ËÄÅÊú∫Âô®ËΩ¨Êç¢‰∏∫¬†Â™í‰ΩìÊúçÂä°Âô®„ÄÅÂ≠òÂÇ®ÊúçÂä°Âô®ÔºåÁ≠âÁ≠â„ÄÇ Âú®ËøôÈáåÔºåÊàëÂπ∂‰∏çÊòØË¶ÅÁªô‰Ω†‰∏Ä‰∫õÂ¶Ç‰ΩïË¥°ÁåÆÊõ¥Â§öÁöÑÁîµÂ≠êÂûÉÂúæÁöÑÊÄùË∑Ø„ÄÇÂ∞ΩÂèØËÉΩÈïøÂú∞Âà©Áî®‰Ω†ÁöÑÁ°¨‰ª∂ÔºåËÄå‰∏çÊõ¥Êç¢ÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÊÄªÊòØÂ•ΩÁöÑ„ÄÇ ÁÑ∂ËÄåÔºå‰∏ç‰ΩøÁî® 32 ‰ΩçÁ≥ªÁªüÁöÑÁêÜÁî±ÂèØËÉΩÊØî‰ª•ÂæÄÊõ¥ÊúâËØ¥ÊúçÂäõ„ÄÇÂÖ≥ÈîÆÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÊòØÂú®ÂÆâÂÖ®ÂíåÁª¥Êä§ÊñπÈù¢„ÄÇ Âà©Áî® 64 ‰Ωç Linux ÊèêÈ´òÂÆâÂÖ®ÊÄß 2018 Âπ¥ÔºåÂç±Èô©ÁöÑÂ§ÑÁêÜÂô®ÂÆâÂÖ®ÈóÆÈ¢ò Spectre ÊºèÊ¥ûÂºïÂèë‰∫ÜÁÉ≠ËÆÆ„ÄÇËôΩÁÑ∂Ëã±ÁâπÂ∞îÂíå AMD ÂØπËøô‰∏™ÊºèÊ¥ûËøõË°å‰∫Ü‰øÆÂ§çÔºå‰ΩÜÊÉÖÂÜµÂπ∂‰∏ç‰πêËßÇ„ÄÇ ‰∏çÂπ∏ÁöÑÊòØÔºå‰∏Ä‰∏™Êñ∞ÁöÑÊºèÊ¥û RetbleedÔºåÂÆÉÊòØ Spectre ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂèòÁßçÔºåÊ≠£Âú®ÂΩ±ÂìçËã±ÁâπÂ∞îÂíå AMD ËäØÁâá„ÄÇ ‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®‰∏ãÈù¢Áî±ÂèëÁé∞ÂÆÉÁöÑÁ†îÁ©∂‰∫∫ÂëòÂàÜ‰∫´ÁöÑËßÜÈ¢ë‰∏≠ÁúãÂà∞ÂÆÉÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ„ÄÇ Âõ†Ê≠§ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Ëá™ÁÑ∂ÈúÄË¶ÅÈÄÇÂΩìÁöÑÊé™ÊñΩÊù•Ëß£ÂÜ≥Ëøô‰∏™Êñ∞ÁöÑÂÆâÂÖ®ÊºèÊ¥ûÁöÑ‰øÆÂ§çÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ ‰ª§‰∫∫ÈúáÊÉäÁöÑ‰∫ãÊÉÖÊù•‰∫Ü„ÄÇ64 ‰Ωç Linux ÂÜÖÊ†∏Â∑≤ÁªèÊî∂Âà∞‰∫ÜÂØπÂÆÉÁöÑ‰øÆÂ§çÔºå‰ª•‰øùÊä§ÊúâÂÖ≥ÁöÑËã±ÁâπÂ∞î/AMD ÁöÑÂ§ÑÁêÜÂô®„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÔºåÊ≠£Â¶Ç¬†Phoronix¬†ÊâÄÊä•ÈÅìÁöÑÔºåLinux 32 ‰ΩçÂÜÖÊ†∏‰ªçÁÑ∂ÂÆπÊòìÂèóÂà∞ Retbleed ÊºèÊ¥ûÁöÑÂΩ±Âìç„ÄÇ Ëã±ÁâπÂ∞îÁöÑ Pawan Gupta Âú®¬†ÂÜÖÊ†∏ÈÇÆ‰ª∂ÂàóË°®¬†‰∏≠ÂõûÂ∫î‰∫ÜËøô‰∫õÊãÖÂøßÔºå‰ªñÊèêÂà∞Ôºö Ëã±ÁâπÂ∞î‰∏çÁü•ÈÅìËøòÊúâË∞ÅÂú® Skylake ÈÇ£‰∏Ä‰ª£ÁöÑ CPU ‰∏ä‰ΩøÁî® 32 ‰ΩçÊ®°ÂºèÁöÑÁîü‰∫ßÁéØÂ¢É„ÄÇÊâÄ‰ª•Ëøô‰∏çÂ∫îËØ•ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ Âè¶Â§ñÔºåÂæàÂ∞ëÁúãÂà∞‰∏∫ 32 ‰ΩçÁª¥Êä§ÊâÄÂÅöÁöÑ‰ªª‰ΩïÂä™Âäõ„ÄÇÊâÄ‰ª•ÔºåËøôÂ∫îËØ•‰∏çÁÆó‰ªÄ‰πàÊÑèÂ§ñ„ÄÇ ÂΩìÁÑ∂ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆåÂÖ®Á¶ªÁ∫øÁöÑÁéØÂ¢ÉÂèØ‰ª•ÁÆóÂÅö‰æãÂ§ñ„ÄÇÊâÄ‰ª•Ôºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ËøôÊ†∑ÂÅöÔºå‰ΩÜ‰∏çÂª∫ËÆÆËøôÊ†∑ÂÅö„ÄÇ ‰∏çÂÖ≥ÂøÉÂÆâÂÖ®ÈóÆÈ¢òÔºü Âç≥‰Ωø‰Ω†ËÆ§‰∏∫Âæó‰∏çÂà∞ÂÉè Retbleed ËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂÆâÂÖ®‰øÆÂ§çÊ≤°ÊúâÂÖ≥Á≥ªÔºå2022 Âπ¥ÁöÑ 32 ‰ΩçÁ≥ªÁªü‰πü‰ºöÊúâÊõ¥Â§öÁöÑÈ∫ªÁÉ¶„ÄÇ ËΩØ‰ª∂Áª¥Êä§ËÄÖ‰ª¨ÊúÄÁªà‰ºöÊîæÂºÉÂØπ 32 ‰ΩçÁ≥ªÁªü‰∏äÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑Âíå Linux ÂèëË°åÁâàÁöÑÊõ¥Êñ∞„ÄÇ ÂêóÔºü‰Ω†ÂØπÊ≠§Êúâ‰ªÄ‰πàÁúãÊ≥ïÔºüÂú®‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑËØÑËÆ∫‰∏≠ÂàÜ‰∫´‰Ω†ÁöÑÊÉ≥Ê≥ï„ÄÇ via:¬†https://news.itsfoss.com/64-bit-linux/ ‰ΩúËÄÖÔºöAnkush Das¬†ÈÄâÈ¢òÔºölujun9972¬†ËØëËÄÖÔºölkxed„ÄÅwxy¬†Ê†°ÂØπÔºöwxy     Á°¨Ê†∏ËßÇÂØü #712 UEFI ÊîªÂáªÂØπÊàë‰ª¨Êù•ËØ¥ÊòØÂá†‰πéÊòØ‰∏çÂèØËßÅÁöÑ
    UEFI ÊîªÂáªÂØπÊàë‰ª¨Êù•ËØ¥ÊòØÂá†‰πéÊòØ‰∏çÂèØËßÅÁöÑ ÂÆâÂÖ®Á†îÁ©∂‰∫∫ÂëòÂèëÁé∞ UEFI ÁöÑ Rootkit Âπ∂‰∏çÁΩïËßÅÔºåËÄå‰∏îÈöæ‰ª•Ê£ÄÊµã„ÄÇÂç°Â∑¥ÊñØÂü∫Á†îÁ©∂‰∫∫ÂëòÂú®ÂØπ‰∏ÄÁßçÂ§çÊùÇÁöÑ UEFI Rootkit Á†îÁ©∂ÂêéË°®Á§∫Ôºö‚ÄúËøôÁßç UEFI Ê§çÂÖ•Áâ©‰ºº‰πéËá™ 2016 Âπ¥Â∫ï‰ª•Êù•Â∞±Â∑≤ÁªèÂú®ÈáéÂ§ñ‰ΩøÁî®ÔºåËøôÁîöËá≥Êó©Âú® UEFI ÊîªÂáªÂºÄÂßãË¢´ÂÖ¨ÂºÄÊèèËø∞‰πãÂâç„ÄÇ‚Äù Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöARS Technica ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöËøôËØ¥ÊòéÂæàÂèØËÉΩÂú®Êàë‰ª¨ÈÉΩÊØ´‰∏çÁü•ÊÉÖÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåÂ∑≤ÁªèË¢´ÂÅ∑ÂÅ∑ÂÖ•‰æµÂíåÁ™ÉÂèñ‰∫ÜÂæàÂ§ö‰ø°ÊÅØ„ÄÇ DeepMind ÂèëÂ∏ÉÂá†‰πéÊâÄÊúâÂ∑≤Áü•ËõãÁôΩË¥®ÁöÑÈ¢ÑÊµãÁªìÊûÑ ËõãÁôΩË¥®Áî±Ê∞®Âü∫ÈÖ∏ÈìæÁªÑÊàêÔºåÊäòÂè†ÊàêÂ§çÊùÇÁöÑÂΩ¢Áä∂ÔºåËøôÂú®ÂæàÂ§ßÁ®ãÂ∫¶‰∏äÂÜ≥ÂÆö‰∫ÜÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÁöÑÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇ‰∏ÄÊó¶‰Ω†Áü•ÈÅìËõãÁôΩË¥®ÊòØÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊäòÂè†ÁöÑÔºå‰Ω†Â∞±ÂèØ‰ª•ÂºÄÂßã‰∫ÜËß£ÂÆÉÊòØÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂ∑•‰ΩúÁöÑÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊîπÂèòÂÆÉÁöÑË°å‰∏∫„ÄÇ2020 Âπ¥ 11 ÊúàÔºåDeepMind ÂÆ£Â∏ÉÂ∑≤ÂºÄÂèëÂá∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Âêç‰∏∫ AlphaFold ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫èÔºåÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®ÁÆóÊ≥ïÂø´ÈÄüÈ¢ÑÊµãÂÖ∂ÁªìÊûÑ„ÄÇÂéªÂπ¥ÔºåDeepMind ÂèëÂ∏É‰∫Ü 20 ‰∏™Áâ©ÁßçÁöÑËõãÁôΩË¥®ÁªìÊûÑ‚Äî‚ÄîÂåÖÊã¨‰∫∫Á±ªË°®ËææÁöÑÂá†‰πéÊâÄÊúâ 20,000 ÁßçËõãÁôΩË¥®„ÄÇÁé∞Âú®ÂÆÉÂ∑≤ÁªèÂÆåÊàê‰∫ÜËøôÈ°πÂ∑•‰ΩúÔºåÂπ∂ÂèëÂ∏É‰∫ÜË∂ÖËøá 2 ‰∫øÁßçËõãÁôΩË¥®ÁöÑÈ¢ÑÊµãÁªìÊûÑ„ÄÇÂü∫Êú¨‰∏äÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ËÆ§‰∏∫ÂÆÉÊ∂µÁõñ‰∫ÜÊï¥‰∏™ËõãÁôΩË¥®ÂÆáÂÆô„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöÂç´Êä• ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöËøôÊâçÊòØ AI Â∫îËØ•ÈÄ†Á¶è‰∫∫Á±ªÁöÑÂú∞ÊñπÔºåËÄå‰∏çÊòØÁî®Âú®ÁõëÊéß„ÄÅÊ∑±Â∫¶‰º™ÈÄ†ËøôÁßçÂú∞Êñπ„ÄÇ Êñ∞Áâà GB18030 Â≠óÁ¨¶ÈõÜÊ†áÂáÜÂèëÂ∏É Â∏ÇÂú∫ÁõëÁÆ°ÊÄªÂ±ÄÊ†áÂáÜÂßîÂèëÂ∏É‰∫ÜÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑ GB 18030 ‰∏≠ÊñáÁºñÁ†ÅÂ≠óÁ¨¶ÈõÜ„ÄÇGB 18030 È¶ñÊ¨°ÂèëÂ∏É‰∫é 2000 Âπ¥Ôºå2005 Âπ¥Á¨¨‰∏ÄÊ¨°‰øÆËÆ¢ÔºåËøôÊòØÁ¨¨‰∫åÊ¨°‰øÆËÆ¢„ÄÇ2022 Ê†áÂáÜÂ∞Ü‰∫é 2023 Âπ¥ 8 Êúà 1 Êó•Ê≠£ÂºèÂÆûÊñΩÔºåÂÖ±Êî∂ÂΩïÊ±âÂ≠ó 87887 ‰∏™ÔºåÊØî‰∏ä‰∏ÄÁâàÂ¢ûÂä†ÂΩïÂÖ•‰∫Ü 1.7 ‰∏á‰Ωô‰∏™ÁîüÂÉªÊ±âÂ≠ó„ÄÇÈô§‰∫ÜÊ±âÂ≠óÔºåËøòÂåÖÊã¨‰∫Ü 10 ÁßçÊàëÂõΩÁöÑÂ∞ëÊï∞Ê∞ëÊóèËØ≠Ë®ÄÁöÑÊñáÂ≠ó„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöÊñ∞ÂçéÁΩë ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöËøôÊòØÂçÅÂ§öÂπ¥Êù•Âèà‰∏ÄÊ¨°‰øÆËÆ¢Ôºå‰∏çËøáÁé∞Âú®Êõ¥Â§öÁî®ÁöÑÊòØ Unicode ‰∫Ü„ÄÇ  ( 2 min )
    Â≠¶‰π† ReactJS ‰πãÂâçÔºå‰Ω†ÈúÄË¶Å‰∫ÜËß£Â§öÂ∞ë JavaScriptÔºü
    ÊúÄ‰∏ªË¶ÅÁöÑÊòØË¶ÅÁ≤æÈÄö JavaScriptÔºåËøôÊ†∑‰Ω†Â∞±ÂèØ‰ª•ÂáèÂ∞ë ReactJS ‰πãÊóÖÁöÑÂ§çÊùÇÊÄß„ÄÇ React ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Âª∫Á´ãÂú® HTML„ÄÅCSS Âíå JavaScript ‰πã‰∏äÁöÑ UI Ê°ÜÊû∂ÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ JavaScriptÔºàJSÔºâË¥üË¥£Â§ßÈÉ®ÂàÜÁöÑÈÄªËæë„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÂØπÂèòÈáè„ÄÅÊï∞ÊçÆÁ±ªÂûã„ÄÅÊï∞ÁªÑÂáΩÊï∞„ÄÅÂõûË∞É„ÄÅ‰ΩúÁî®Âüü„ÄÅÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ÊñπÊ≥ï„ÄÅÂæ™ÁéØÂíåÂÖ∂‰ªñ JS DOM Êìç‰ΩúÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑ‰∏ªÈ¢òÊúâ‰∏ÄÂÆö‰∫ÜËß£ÔºåËøô‰∫õÂ∞ÜÊûÅÂ§ßÂú∞Âä†Âø´Â≠¶‰π† ReactJS ÁöÑÊ≠•‰ºê„ÄÇ ‰Ω†ÂØπÁé∞‰ª£ JavaScript ÁöÑÊ¶ÇÂøµÂ∞ÜÂÜ≥ÂÆö‰Ω†ËÉΩÂ§öÂø´Âú∞ÊéåÊè° ReactJS ÁöÑÊ≠•‰ºê„ÄÇ‰Ω†‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÊàê‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ JavaScript ‰∏ìÂÆ∂Êù•ÂºÄÂßã‰Ω†ÁöÑ ReactJS ‰πãÊóÖÔºå‰ΩÜÂ∞±ÂÉèÂØπÈ£üÊùêÁöÑ‰∫ÜËß£ÊòØ‰ªª‰ΩïÂ∏åÊúõÊéåÊè°ÁÉπÈ•™ÁöÑÂé®Â∏àÊâÄÂøÖÈ°ªÁöÑ‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÔºåÂ≠¶‰π† ReactJS ‰πüÊòØÂ¶ÇÊ≠§„ÄÇÂÆÉÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Áé∞‰ª£ÁöÑ JavaScript UI Â∫ìÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•‰Ω†ÈúÄË¶Å‰∫ÜËß£‰∏Ä‰∫õ JavaScript„ÄÇÈóÆÈ¢òÊòØÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂ§öÂ∞ëÔºü Á§∫‰æãËß£Èáä ÂÅáËÆæÊàëË¢´Ë¶ÅÊ±ÇÁî®Ëã±ËØ≠ÂÜô‰∏ÄÁØáÂÖ≥‰∫é‚ÄúÁâõ‚ÄùÁöÑÊñáÁ´†Ôºå‰ΩÜÊàëÂØπËøôÁßçËØ≠Ë®Ä‰∏ÄÊó†ÊâÄÁü•„ÄÇÂú®ËøôÁßçÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºå‰∏∫‰∫ÜËÆ©ÊàëÊàêÂäüÂú∞ÂÆåÊàê‰ªªÂä°ÔºåÊàë‰∏ç‰ªÖË¶ÅÂØπ‰∏ªÈ¢òÊúâÊ¶ÇÂøµÔºåËøòË¶ÅÂØπÊåáÂÆöÁöÑËØ≠Ë®ÄÊúâÊ¶ÇÂøµ„ÄÇ ÂÅáËÆæÊàëËé∑Âæó‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∫õÂÖ≥‰∫é‰∏ªÈ¢òÔºàÁâõÔºâÁöÑÁü•ËØÜÔºåÊàëÂ¶Ç‰ΩïËÆ°ÁÆóÊàëÈúÄË¶ÅÁü•ÈÅìÂ§öÂ∞ëËã±ËØ≠ÊâçËÉΩÂÜôÂá∫ËßÑÂÆöÁöÑ‰∏ªÈ¢òÔºüÂ¶ÇÊûúÊàëÂøÖÈ°ªÁî®Ëã±ËØ≠ÂÜô‰∏ÄÁØáÂÖ≥‰∫éÂÖ∂‰ªñÂ§çÊùÇËØùÈ¢òÁöÑÊñáÁ´†Âë¢Ôºü ËøôÂæàÈöæÊêûÊ∏ÖÊ•öÔºå‰∏çÊòØÂêóÔºüÊàë‰∏çÁü•ÈÅìÊàëË¶ÅÂÜôÂÖ≥‰∫éËøô‰∏™ËØùÈ¢òÁöÑ‰ªÄ‰πà‰∏úË•øÔºå‰ΩÜÂÆÉÂèØËÉΩÊòØ‰ªª‰Ωï‰∏úË•ø„ÄÇÊâÄ‰ª•Ë¶ÅÊÉ≥ÂºÄÂßãÔºåÊàëÂøÖÈ°ªË¶ÅÊúâÈÄÇÂΩìÁöÑËã±ËØ≠Áü•ËØÜÔºå‰ΩÜËøò‰∏çÊ≠¢‰∫éÊ≠§„ÄÇ ÊûÅÁ´ØÁé∞ÂÆû Âú®ÂºÄÂßã‰ΩøÁî® ReactJS ‰πãÂâçÔºåÊâÄÈúÄÁöÑ JavaScript Êï∞Èáè‰πüÊòØÂ¶ÇÊ≠§„ÄÇÊ†πÊçÆÊàëÁöÑ‰æãÂ≠êÊÉÖÊôØÔºåReactJS ÊòØËØùÈ¢ò‚ÄúÁâõ‚ÄùÔºåËÄå JavaScript ÊòØËã±ËØ≠„ÄÇË¶ÅÊÉ≥Âú® ReactJS ‰∏≠Ëé∑ÂæóÊàêÂäüÔºåÂØπ JavaScript ÁöÑÊéåÊè°ÂæàÈáçË¶Å„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûúÊ≤°ÊúâÈÄÇÂΩìÁöÑ JavaScript Âü∫Á°ÄÔºå‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫∫ÊòØÂæàÈöæ‰∏ì‰∏öÂú∞ÊéåÊè° ReactJS ÁöÑ„ÄÇÊó†ËÆ∫ÊàëÂØπËøô‰∏™‰∏ªÈ¢òÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÁü•ËØÜÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊàë‰∏çÁü•ÈÅìËØ≠Ë®ÄÁöÑÂü∫Á°ÄÔºåÊàëÂ∞±‰∏çËÉΩÊ≠£Á°ÆÂú∞Ë°®ËææËá™Â∑±„ÄÇ Â§öÂ∞ëÊâçÁÆóÂ§üÔºü Ê†πÊçÆÊàëÁöÑÁªèÈ™åÔºåÂΩì‰Ω†ÂºÄÂßã‰Ω†ÁöÑ ReactJS ‰πãÊóÖÊó∂Ôºå‰Ω†Â∫îËØ•Â∑≤ÁªèÁÜüÊÇâ‰∫ÜÔºö ÂèòÈáè Êï∞ÊçÆÁ±ªÂûã Â≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ÊñπÊ≥ï Âæ™ÁéØ Êù°‰ª∂Âºè ‰Ω†Â∫îËØ•ÂØπËøô‰∫õÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑ JavaScript ÁÜüÊÇâ„ÄÇ‰ΩÜËøô‰∫õÂè™ÊòØÊúÄÂü∫Êú¨ÁöÑÂÖàÂÜ≥Êù°‰ª∂„ÄÇÂΩì‰Ω†ËØïÂõæÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑ React Â∫îÁî®Êó∂Ôºå‰Ω†Â∞Ü‰∏çÂèØÈÅøÂÖçÂú∞ÈúÄË¶ÅÂ§ÑÁêÜ‰∫ã‰ª∂„ÄÇÊâÄ‰ª•ÔºåÊôÆÈÄöÂáΩÊï∞„ÄÅÂáΩÊï∞Ë°®ËææÂºè„ÄÅËØ≠Âè•„ÄÅÁÆ≠Â§¥ÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÊ¶ÇÂøµÔºåÁÆ≠Â§¥ÂáΩÊï∞ÂíåÊôÆÈÄöÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂå∫Âà´Ôºå‰ª•ÂèäËøô‰∏§Á±ªÂáΩÊï∞‰∏≠¬†this¬†ÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂ≠óÁöÑËØç‰πâËåÉÂõ¥ÔºåËøôÁ°ÆÂÆûÂæàÈáçË¶Å„ÄÇ ‰ΩÜÈóÆÈ¢òÊòØÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊàëÂøÖÈ°ª‰ΩøÁî® ReactJS ÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§çÊùÇÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®ÊÄé‰πàÂäûÔºü Ëé∑ÂæóÂêØÂèë Âú® JavaScript ‰∏≠Â§ÑÁêÜ‰∫ã‰ª∂„ÄÅ‰º†Êí≠Êìç‰ΩúÁ¨¶„ÄÅËß£ÊûÑ„ÄÅÂëΩÂêçÂØºÂÖ•ÂíåÈªòËÆ§ÂØºÂÖ•Â∞ÜÂ∏ÆÂä©‰Ω†ÁêÜËß£ React ‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÊú∫Âà∂„ÄÇ ÊúÄÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÊòØÔºå‰Ω†ÂøÖÈ°ª‰∫ÜËß£ JavaScript Êú¨Ë∫´ËÉåÂêéÁöÑÊ†∏ÂøÉÊ¶ÇÂøµ„ÄÇJavaScript Âú®ËÆæËÆ°‰∏äÊòØÂºÇÊ≠•ÁöÑ„ÄÇÂΩìÂá∫Áé∞Âú®Êñá‰ª∂Â∫ïÈÉ®ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÂú®Êñá‰ª∂È°∂ÈÉ®ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†Å‰πãÂâçÊâßË°åÊó∂Ôºå‰∏çË¶ÅÊÉäËÆ∂„ÄÇÂÉè promise„ÄÅcallback„ÄÅasync-await„ÄÅmap„ÄÅfilter Âíå reduce ËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÁªìÊûÑÔºåÊòØ ReactJS ‰∏≠ÊúÄÂ∏∏ËßÅÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÂíåÊ¶ÇÂøµÔºåÂ∞§ÂÖ∂ÊòØÂú®ÂºÄÂèëÂ§çÊùÇÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®Êó∂„ÄÇ ÊúÄ‰∏ªË¶ÅÁöÑÊòØË¶ÅÁ≤æÈÄö JavaScriptÔºåËøôÊ†∑‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÂáèÂ∞ë ReactJS ‰πãÊóÖÁöÑÂ§çÊùÇÊÄß„ÄÇ Ë∂äÊù•Ë∂äÂ•Ω ÊàëÂæàÂÆπÊòìËØ¥Âá∫‰Ω†ÈúÄË¶ÅÁü•ÈÅìÁöÑ‰∏úË•øÔºå‰ΩÜ‰Ω†ÂéªÂ≠¶‰π†ÂÆÉÂÆåÂÖ®ÊòØÂè¶‰∏ÄÂõû‰∫ã„ÄÇÂ§ßÈáèÁªÉ‰π† JavaScript ÊòØÂøÖ‰∏çÂèØÂ∞ëÁöÑÔºå‰ΩÜ‰Ω†ÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöÊÑüÂà∞ÊÉäËÆ∂ÔºåÊàëËÆ§‰∏∫ËøôÂπ∂‰∏çÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄ‰Ω†ÂøÖÈ°ªÁ≠âÂà∞ÊéåÊè°ÂÆÉ„ÄÇÊúâ‰∫õÊ¶ÇÂøµ‰∫ãÂÖàÂæàÈáçË¶ÅÔºå‰ΩÜ‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®Â≠¶‰π†ËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠Â≠¶Âà∞ÂæàÂ§ö‰∏úË•ø„ÄÇÁªÉ‰π†ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜÊòØÂ≠¶‰π†ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÂºÄÂßã‰ΩøÁî® JavaScriptÔºåÁîöËá≥ÊòØ React ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∫õÂü∫Á°ÄÁü•ËØÜÔºåÂè™Ë¶Å‰Ω†‰ª•ËàíÈÄÇÁöÑÈÄüÂ∫¶ÁßªÂä®Âπ∂ÁêÜËß£Âú®‰Ω†Â∞ùËØï‰ªª‰Ωï‰∏•ËÇÉÁöÑ‰∫ãÊÉÖ‰πãÂâçÂÅö‰Ω†ÁöÑ‚ÄúÂÆ∂Â∫≠‰Ωú‰∏ö‚ÄùÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Ë¶ÅÊ±Ç„ÄÇ Á´ãÂç≥ÂºÄÂßã‰ΩøÁî® JavaScript ‰∏çË¶ÅË¥πÂøÉÁ≠âÂà∞‰Ω†‰∫ÜËß£‰∫Ü JavaScript ÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÊñπÈù¢„ÄÇÈÇ£Ê∞∏Ëøú‰∏ç‰ºöÂèëÁîü„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûúËøôÊ†∑ÂÅöÔºå‰Ω†Â∞ÜÈô∑ÂÖ•Â≠¶‰π† JavaScript ÁöÑÊ∞∏ËøúÂæ™ÁéØ‰∏≠„ÄÇ‰Ω†‰ª¨ÈÉΩÁü•ÈÅìÊäÄÊúØÈ¢ÜÂüüÊòØÂ¶Ç‰Ωï‰∏çÊñ≠ÂèëÂ±ïÂíåËøÖÈÄüÂèòÂåñÁöÑ„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÊÉ≥ÂºÄÂßãÂ≠¶‰π† JavaScriptÔºåËØ∑Â∞ùËØïÈòÖËØª Mandy Kendall ÁöÑ‰ªãÁªçÊÄßÊñáÁ´†¬†ÈÄöËøáÁºñÂÜôÁåúË∞úÊ∏∏ÊàèÂ≠¶‰π† JavaScript„ÄÇËøôÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÂø´ÈÄüÂÖ•Èó®ÁöÑÂ•ΩÊñπÊ≥ïÔºåÂΩì‰Ω†ÁúãÂà∞‰∫ÜÂèØËÉΩÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµÔºåÊàëËÆ§‰∏∫‰Ω†ÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöÂèëÁé∞ÂæàÈöæÂÅú‰∏ãÊù•„ÄÇ     How to use Steam‚Äôs FPS counter
    It takes about five seconds to set up. If you want to know what frame rates your Steam games are running at, there are many third-party programs out there to help. But if all you need is a very basic counter and you don‚Äôt care about other hardware stats, you don‚Äôt need to download any of these ‚Äî you can use a feature that‚Äôs built right into Steam. Here‚Äôs how to set up Steam‚Äôs built-in FPS counter for your PC. I go with the top left, myself. Open Steam. Go to Steam > Settings > In-Game. Under In-game FPS counter, select the corner where you‚Äôd like the counter to appear. You can also check High contrast color if you prefer. Click Ok. Now, go ahead and start your game. You should see the frame rate your game is running at displayed in the corner that you... Continue reading‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )

    Sony warns of weaker PlayStation business as game sales wobble
    Photo by Vjeran Pavic / The Verge Sony has cut its annual profit outlook, warning of weaker PlayStation game sales. The forecast comes as Sony revealed it shipped 2.4 million PlayStation 5 consoles in its recent quarter, up only 4 percent from the 2.3 million shipped during the same period last year. PS5 lifetime shipments have now reached 21.7 million. While hardware sales are slightly up year over year, software sales have plummeted 26 percent. In an investor call, Sony blamed the game slump on a lack of big PlayStation titles this year compared to 2021 and less time spent playing games in general ‚Äî backed up by monthly active PlayStation Network users dropping 3 percent to 102 million. Sony released its exclusive Gran Turismo 7 and Horizon Forbidden West titles... Continue reading‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )

From there, they can add things like text, filters, as well as additional videos shot with the Shorts camera or pulled from their photo library.     Meta will stop paying US publishers to put their content in Facebook‚Äôs News tab
    Facebook News tab (2019) | Image: Facebook As you‚Äôve probably heard, Facebook and Instagram will lean heavily into AI-curated creator content going forward, and the News Tab project Facebook launched a few years ago doesn‚Äôt seem to be a big part of that. As reported by Axios and confirming earlier rumors, Facebook‚Äôs parent company Meta is telling publishers it no longer plans to pay for the content it has been aggregating in the news tab. According to the report, Meta spent about $105 million in three-year content deals for news (plus another $90 million for news videos), including $10 million for the Wall Street Journal, $20 million for the New York Times, and $3 million for CNN in arrangements that sometimes included unlocked access to paywalled content.     Valve won‚Äôt allow awards and reviews on Steam store images starting in September
    Valve‚Äôs new rules will prohibit text like this on an image. | Screenshot by Jay Peters / The Verge Valve is making a big change to the way developers can market their games on Steam. Beginning September 1st, graphical assets developers use in their store listings will only be able to include game artwork, the game‚Äôs name, and any official subtitle. Images won‚Äôt be able to include review scores, award names or logos, text that markets discounts, or text promoting a different product. The new rules could prove to be a drastic shift for some developers, as they may rely on reviews or awards on their images in an effort to stand out from the humongous number of games available on Steam. ËøÑ‰ªä‰∏∫Ê≠¢ÈùûÂ∏∏ÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊîπËøõÔºå‰∏ç‰ªÖÂ∏¶Êù•Êõ¥Âä†‰∏ÄËá¥ÁöÑ‰ΩìÈ™åÔºåÂêåÊó∂‰πüÂ§ßÂ§ßÊèêÂçáÊïàÁéá„ÄÇËß£ÂÜ≥Ëøô‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢òÂÖ∂ÂÆûÊúâÁÇπÂë®ÊäòÔºåÊàëÂÖàÁÆÄÂçïÂú∞Ë°•ÂÖÖ‰∏Ä‰∏ãËÉåÊôØÔºö Word Âíå PagesÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂÖ∂Âõ∫ÊúâÊú∫Âà∂ÁöÑÂéüÂõ†Ôºà‰πüËÆ∏ÊòØ BugÔºâÔºåÂÆÉ‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÂâ™Ë¥¥ÊùøÁöÑÂ§öÈ°πÁõÆÁ≤òË¥¥„ÄÇ‰πüÂ∞±ËØ¥ÊòØÔºåÂæÄÂâ™Ë¥¥ÊùøÈáåÂÜôÂÖ•Â§öÈ°πÂÜÖÂÆπÔºåÂÜçÂú® Word     In the previous part of this guide, we deployed the Django web application on AWS ECS. In this part, we'll create a PostgreSQL RDS instance on AWS, connect it to the Django ECS task and enable access to Django Admin. We choose PostgreSQL because it supports complex SQL queries, MVCC, good performance for concurrent queries, and has a large community. As AWS says: PostgreSQL has become the preferred open source relational database for many enterprise developers and start-ups, powering leading business and mobile applications. Amazon RDS makes it easy to set up, operate, and scale PostgreSQL deployments in the cloud.     I can create software 234 billion times faster than you
    Disclaimer, it's not as much about "me" as it is about the tools that we provide at Aista. However, according to research in the subject, the average (human) software developer can produce between 325 and 750 lines of code per month. If I have a really fast computer, I can make Magic produce 1,000,000 lines of code per second. If you calculate the ratio here, you'll see that Magic is 234,000,000,000 times faster than a human being. Time is interesting. As we reduced the required time needed to assemble books, we reduced the cost of books 1 million times. As a consequence, the number of books exploded, and we entered the era of enlightenment as a consequence. In fact, the modern era is nothing but the "bastard child of Gutenberg".     Amazing CSS transition tips and details
    In CSS, the transition property is used to specify adding transition effects to one or more CSS properties. The most common usage is to add a transition to an element, so that when one of its properties changes from state A to state B, it is no longer very direct and obtrusive, but with a tween animation. For example: div { width: 140px; height: 64px; transition: .8s transform linear; } div:hover { transform: translate(120px, 0); } Of course, in addition to the above basic usage, there are actually some very interesting details and interesting usages of CSS transition. Let me explain them one by one. Not all properties support transitions. Similar to animation, here is a list of all properties that support transitions -- CSS animated properties Of course, som‚Ä¶  ( 8 min )

    How to build a live streaming app?
    What is a Live Streaming App? Live streaming technology allows you to broadcast, watch, create and share videos in real-time. All you need to be able to live stream is an internet-enabled device, like a smartphone or tablet, and a platform (such as a website or app) to live stream. Live streaming apps are rapidly developing, given this trend's tremendous opportunities in many fields. Depending on the domain, the basic requirements for building a live streaming app differ as follows: Game live streaming app - The picture must be clear and smooth to construct a game live streaming app. Entertainment live streaming app - Building an entertainment app requires various interactive functions such as gifts, barrage, and mini-games. Shopping live streaming app - It must provide functions such as‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )
    Why SQL Databases Don't Scale
    Structured Query Language (SQL) databases are the go to solution for most small projects and products. They provide a high performance way to query relational data across many different axis. However, SQL databases have problems scaling which is why most companies eventually find themselves moving off SQL solutions and onto NoSQL alternatives. So why don't SQL databases scale? SQL databases rely on structured data and foreign keys to connect data. This is an extremely performant way to manage data and lets you link data across the whole database with simple queries using SELECT and JOIN. SELECT Customers.CustomerName, Orders.OrderID FROM Customers LEFT JOIN Orders ON Customers.CustomerID=Orders.CustomerID ORDER BY Customers.CustomerName; In order for a database to join data this way it n‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )

    Deploy a PHP(Laravel) app on AWS Elastic Beanstalk via Codepipeline
    In this tutorial I will explain you to deploy a PHP laravel application on AWS Elastic Beanstalk service. About : Amazon Elastic Beanstalk is an easy-to-use service for deploying and scaling web applications and services developed with Java, .NET, PHP, Node.js, Python, Ruby, Go, and Docker on familiar servers such as Apache, Nginx, Passenger, and IIS. Working: You simply upload your code and Elastic Beanstalk automatically handles the deployment, from capacity provisioning, load balancing, and automatic scaling to web application health monitoring, with ongoing fully managed patch and security updates.     Filter Java Stream to 1 and Only 1 Element
    Learn two methods from Collectors to retrieve the unique element which matches a certain predicate in a given stream of elements.
    Java Weekly, Issue 448
    Storing monetary values, GraalVM enhancements, project Amber, backend for frontends, and predicting OOMs!

  • Open

    Learn Rust by debugging Rust
    Learn Rust by debugging Rust Gaurav Kamathe Fri, 07/29/2022 - 03:00 Register or Login to like Register or Login to like In my previous¬†article about rustup, I showed you how to install the Rust toolchain. Well, what good is the toolchain if you won‚Äôt be using it to get more hands-on with Rust? Learning any language involves reading existing code and writing a lot of sample programs. That's a good way to become proficient in a language. However, there's a third way: debugging code. Learning through debugging involves trying to compile a pre-written (buggy) sample program, understanding the errors generated by the compiler, fixing the sample code, and then re-compiling it. Repeat that process until the code successfully compiles and runs. Rustlings is an open source project by the Rust‚Ä¶  ( 8 min )
    Fix bugs in Bash scripts by printing a stack trace
    Fix bugs in Bash scripts by printing a stack trace Evan "Hippy" Slatis Fri, 07/29/2022 - 03:00 Register or Login to like Register or Login to like No one wants to write bad code, but inevitably bugs will be created. Most modern languages like Java, JavaScript, Python, etc., automatically print a stack trace when they encounter an unhandled exception, but not shell scripts. It would make it much easier to find and fix bugs in shell scripts if you could print a stack trace, and, with a little work, you can. Shell scripts can span multiple files, and well-written code is further broken down into functions. Tracing issues when something goes wrong in a shell script can be difficult when these scripts get large enough. A stack trace that walks the code backward from the error to the begin‚Ä¶  ( 8 min )

  • Open

    JankMan-ÊûÅËá¥ÁöÑÂç°È°øÂàÜÊûêÁ≥ªÁªü
    Âç°È°øÂàÜÊûêÁ≥ªÁªü 1.Á≥ªÁªü‰ªãÁªç Ê≠§Á≥ªÁªüÊã•Êúâ‰∫ÜÁ´Ø‰∏äÈááÈõÜ‰∏§‰∏™Áª¥Â∫¶Êï∞ÊçÆÁöÑËÉΩÂäõ ÊñπÊ≥ïËøêË°åÊï∞ÊçÆÔºöÁ≥ªÁªüÂú®ÁºñËØëÊúüÈó¥Âü∫‰∫éASM9+AGP7+Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâÊñπÊ≥ïIDÊò†Â∞Ñ+Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâÂ≠óËäÇÁ†ÅÊåá‰ª§ÈõÜÂÆûÁé∞‰∫ÜÊñπÊ≥ïËøêË°åÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÈááÈõÜ„ÄÇ Â∏ßÊÄßËÉΩÊï∞ÊçÆÔºöÁ≥ªÁªüÂú®ËøêË°åÊúüÈó¥Âü∫‰∫éFrameMatrix+Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâÊï∞ÊçÆÁªìÊûÑ‰ΩìÂÆûÁé∞‰∫ÜÁ´Ø‰∏äÂ∏ßÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÈááÈõÜ„ÄÇ ÂΩìAPPÂèëÁîüËøêË°åÂç°È°øÊó∂ÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂèØËá™Âä®ÂàÜÊûêÂ†ÜÊ†àÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÂÖ≥ËÅîÂç°È°øÂ∏ßÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïË∞ÉÁî®ÈìæÔºåÂπ∂‰ΩúÂá∫ËÆ∞ÂΩïÊúÄÁªàÂØºÂá∫Ëá≥Êñá‰ª∂„ÄÇÊï¥‰ΩìÂü∫‰∫éÂçèÁ®ãÂà∂‰ΩúÔºåÊÄßËÉΩÊçüËÄó‰ªÖÈúÄ1%„ÄÇ Âü∫‰∫éCompose KMPÁã¨Âàõ‰∫ÜÂ§öÁ´ØÂèØÁî®ÁöÑÁ∫ø‰∏ãËøòÂéüÂô®ÔºåÂ∞ÜÈááÈõÜÂà∞ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÂÅöÊ†ºÂºèÊïàÈ™åÔºåÂπ∂‰ΩúÂá∫‰∫åÊ¨°ËøòÂéüËß£ÊûêÔºåËøõË°å‰∫ÜperfettoÁöÑ‰∫åÊ¨°ÂºÄÂèëÔºåÂÆûÁé∞‰∫ÜÂèØËßÜÂåñÂ±ïÁ§∫Êï¥‰Ωì‰ø°ÊÅØÁöÑËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇ 2.ÊÄùË∑Ø‰ªãÁªç 2.1ÊñπÊ≥ïËøêË°åÊï∞ÊçÆÈááÈõÜ 2.1.1ÊñπÊ≥ïIDÊò†Â∞Ñ Áî±‰∫éÁ≥ªÁªü‰ºöÂú®ËøêË°åÊúüÈó¥‰ºöÈááÈõÜÂ§ßÈáèÊï∞ÊçÆÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÈúÄË¶ÅÂ∞ÜÂ∫ûÂ§ßÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÂêçÊò†Â∞Ñ‰∏∫ÊåáÂÆöIDÁöÑËÉΩÂäõÔºåÂ¶Ç‰∏ã //ÊñπÊ≥ïID`ÊñπÊ≥ïÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂÖ®Ë∑ØÂæÑÂíåË°åÂèÇ 24`com.d.hookplus.HookApplication$onCreate$1.onActivitySaveInstanceState[android.app.Activity,android.os.Bundle,] Ê≠§Â§ÑÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÂêçÂåÖÂê´‰∫ÜÂÖ®Ë∑ØÂæÑÂíåË°åÂèÇÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÈÄöËøáÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ËÆ∞ÂΩïÊòØÂçÅÂàÜÂ∫ûÂ§ßÁöÑÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Âú®ÁºñËØëÊúüÈó¥‰ΩøÁî®ASMÊäÄÊúØÂ∞ÜÂÖ∂ÂØπÂ∫îÊàêIDÔºåÈôç‰ΩéÁ©∫Èó¥Â§çÊùÇÂ∫¶ 2.2.2ÂáΩÊï∞ËÆ∞ÂΩïËÉΩÂäõ Âú®ASMËΩÆËÆ≠ÊúüÈó¥ÔºåÂú®ÊñπÊ≥ïÂºÄÂßãÂíåÁªìÊùü‰ΩçÁΩÆÂêÑÊèíÂÖ•ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÊåá‰ª§Áî®‰∫éÂÆûÁé∞Ê†áËÆ∞ÂäüËÉΩ override fun onMethodEnter() { //ÊñπÊ≥ïËøõÂÖ• ¬† ¬†methodVisitor?.perfettoVisitMethodDelegate(PerfettoCentre.const.METHOD_ENTER, methodId) ¬† ¬†super.onMethodEnter() } ‚Äã override fun onMethodExit(‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )

ÂâçË®Ä ‰πãÂâçÂÜôËøá‰∏ÄÁØá „Ää[-NDK ÂØºÂºïÁØá -] Âú®NDKÂºÄÂèë‰πãÂâç‰Ω†Â∫îÁü•ÈÅìÁöÑ‰∏úË•ø„Äã ‰ªãÁªç‰∫ÜÂú®ËøõÂÖ• NDK Â≠¶‰π†‰πãÂâçÔºåÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊëÜÊ≠£Ëá™Â∑±ÁöÑËßíËâ≤„ÄÇÊó∂Èöî‰∏§Âπ¥ÔºåNDK Á≥ªÂàóÊñáÁ´†ÂºÄÂßãÂ°´ÂùëÔºåÂú®‰∏ä‰∏ÄÁØá „Ää NDK ÊòØ‰ªÄ‰πà | FFmpeg 5.0 ÁºñËØë so Â∫ì„Äã ‰∏≠Ôºå‰ªãÁªç‰∫Ü NDK ÁöÑÊ¶ÇÂøµÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÂÖ∂‰ΩúÁî®„ÄÇ Ê≠£ÊâÄË∞ìÔºåÂ∑•Ê¨≤ÂñÑÂÖ∂‰∫ãÂøÖÂÖàÂà©ÂÖ∂Âô®ÔºåÊé•‰∏ãÊù•Â∞ÜÁî® 2~3 ÁØáÊù•Á≥ªÁªü‰ªãÁªç‰∏Ä‰∏ã CMake Âèä CMakeLists.txt ÁöÑËØ≠Ê≥ï„ÄÇCMake ËøôÂùóÁü•ËØÜÊòØÊØîËæÉÁã¨Á´ãÁöÑÔºå‰∏çÊ≠¢ÊòØ Android NDK È°πÁõÆÔºå‰∏ÄËà¨ÁöÑ C++ È°πÁõÆ‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøá CMake ËøõË°åÊûÑÂª∫„ÄÇ‰∏∫‰∫ÜÊõ¥ÂÖ∑Êúâ‰∏ÄËà¨ÊÄßÔºåÂ∞ÜÂú® Linux ÁéØÂ¢É‰∏≠ÔºåÈÄöËøá C++ È°πÁõÆÊù•‰ªãÁªç CMake ÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Áü•ËØÜÔºåÂΩìÁÑ∂Ëøô‰∏ÄÂàá‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Áî®‰∫é Android NDK È°πÁõÆ‰∏≠„ÄÇ CMake Êú¨Ë¥®‰∏äÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ ÁºñËØëÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåÂÖ∂ÊúÄÁªàÁõÆÁöÑÊòØÊñπ‰æøÂú∞ÁîüÊàêÂèØÊâßË°åÊñá‰ª∂ÊàñÂÖ±‰∫´Â∫ì„ÄÇÁºñËØëÁöÑËøáÁ®ãÂíåÈ°πÁõÆÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÔºåÁî± CMakeLists.txt Êñá‰ª∂Ë¥üË¥£ÂÆö‰πâ„ÄÇËøôÂæàÂÉè gradle ÊûÑÂª∫Â∑•ÂÖ∑Âíå build.gradle Êñá‰ª∂‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑÂÖ≥Á≥ªÔºåÂâçËÄÖÊòØÂèØÊâßË°åÊñá‰ª∂ÔºåÂêéËÄÖÊòØÈÖçÁΩÆÂÆö‰πâ„ÄÇ Êó¢ÁÑ∂ cmake ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Â∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåÂú®‰ΩøÁî®ÂÆÉ‰πãÂâçÔºåÈ¶ñÂÖàË¶ÅÊã•ÊúâÂÆÉ„ÄÇ‰∏ÄËà¨ linux ÁéØÂ¢ÉÈÉΩ‰ºöÊúâ CMake , Â¶ÇÊûúÊòØ Windows ÁéØÂ¢ÉÔºåÂú®ÂÆòÁΩë‰∏ãËΩΩ Âç≥ÂèØ„ÄÇÂú®ÁªàÁ´ØËæìÂÖ•Â¶Ç‰∏ãÂëΩ‰ª§ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Êü•ÁúãÁâàÊú¨Âè∑ÔºåÊúâËæìÂá∫Ë°®Á§∫ÁéØÂ¢ÉÊ≠£Â∏∏Ôºö ---> cmake --version cmake version 3.16.3 1. ÂàùËØÜ ‰ΩøÁî® Clion ÂàõÂª∫ÁöÑ c++ È°πÁõÆÔºåÈªòËÆ§ÈÄöËøá CMake ËøõË°åÊûÑÂª∫ÁÆ°ÁêÜ„ÄÇÂèØ‰ª•ÁúãÂá∫ÂÖ∂‰∏≠Êúâ‰∏§‰∏™Êñá‰ª∂Âíå‰∏Ä‰∏™Êñá‰ª∂Â§πÔºåmain.cpp ÊòØÊ∫êÁ†ÅÊñá‰ª∂ÔºåCMakeLists.txt ÊòØÈ°πÁõÆÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇÂè¶Â§ñËØ¥Êòé‰∏ÄÁÇπÔºåËøôÈáå ‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )

    theme: juejin highlight: a11y-dark ÂâçË®Ä Ê£ãÁõò Á¨¨‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÔºåÁîªÊ£ãÁõòÔºåÂõ¥Ê£ã‰∏≠ÔºåÁõÆÂâç‰∏ªÊµÅÁöÑÊ∏∏ÊàèËßÑÂàôÊúâ9„ÄÅ13„ÄÅ19Ë∑Ø‰∏âÁßçÊ£ãÁõòÔºå9Ë∑ØÈÄÇÂêàÊñ∞ÊâãÂÖ•Èó®ÔºåËÄå19Ë∑ØÂàôÊòØÂõ¥Ê£ãÂèëÂ±ïËá≥‰ªäÁöÑÊ†áÂáÜÁöÑÂõ¥Ê£ãÊ£ãÁõòÔºå‰πüÊòØÂêÑÁßçÊØîËµõÈªòËÆ§ÁöÑÂõ¥Ê£ãÊ£ãÁõò„ÄÇ È¢òÂ§ñËØùÔºöËôΩÁÑ∂Âè™ÊòØ19 * 19Ë∑ØÁöÑÊ£ãÁõòÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÂ∞±Âú®ËøôÂ∞èÂ∞èÁöÑÂõ¥Ê£ãÊ£ãÁõò‰∏äÂèØÂá∫Áé∞ÁöÑÂèòÂåñÁªùÂØπÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êó†Ê≥ïÊÉ≥Ë±°ÁöÑÂ§©ÊñáÊï∞Â≠óÔºå‰ª•Ëá≥‰∫éÂõ¥Ê£ãÂèëÂ±ï‰∫Ü2000Â§öÂπ¥ÔºåÂè§‰ªäÊ£ãÂ±ÄËá≥‰ªäÊ≤°ÊúâÂÆåÂÖ®Áõ∏ÂêåÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂ±ÄÊ£ãÔºåÊ≠£ÊâÄË∞ìÂçÉÂè§Êó†ÂêåÂ±ÄËØ¥ÁöÑÂ∞±ÊòØÂõ¥Ê£ãÔºåËøô‰πüÊòØ‰∫∫Á±ªÂØπÂõ¥Ê£ã‰∏∫‰πãÁùÄËø∑ÁöÑÂéüÂõ†ÔºåÊ≠£ÊòØËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÂéüÂõ†Ôºå‰∫∫Á±ªÁõ∏ËæÉ‰∫éÁîµËÑë‰∏ÄÁõ¥ÁªüÊ≤ªÁùÄÂõ¥Ê£ãÊ∏∏ÊàèÊ∞¥Âπ≥ÁöÑÂ§©Ëä±ÊùøÔºåÁõ¥Ëá≥2016Âπ¥GoogleÁ†îÂèëÁöÑAlphagoÈóÆ‰∏ñ‰πãÂêéÔºåÈ¶ñÊ¨°‰∏éÂΩìÊó∂‰∫∫Á±ªÈ°∂Â∞ñÊ£ãÊâãÊùé‰∏ñÁü≥ÁöÑÂØπÂ±Ä‰∏≠Ôºå‰ª•4-1ÊàòÁª©Ê®™Êâ´‰∫∫Á±ªÔºå‰∫∫Á±ªÁªüÊ≤ªÂõ¥Ê£ãÁöÑÁ•ûËØù‰πüÈöè‰πãÂ¥©Â°å‰∫ÜÔºåËÄåËµ¢ÁöÑÈÇ£‰∏ÄÂ±Ä‰πüÊàê‰∏∫‰∫ÜÁõÆÂâç‰∏∫Ê≠¢‰∫∫Á±ªÊàòËÉúAlphagoÁöÑÂîØ‰∏ÄÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂ±ÄÊ£ãÔºå‰πãÂêéAlphagoÊ®™Êâ´Âõ¥Ê£ãÊ£ãÂùõÔºåÂØπÊàò‰∫∫Á±ªÂÜçÊó†Ë¥•Áª©Ôºå‰πü‰æßÈù¢ËØ¥Êòé‰∫Ü‰∫∫Á±ªÂØπ‰∫éÂõ¥Ê£ãÂΩì‰∏≠Êó†Á©∑Â••ÁßòÁöÑÊéåÊè°È¶ñÊ¨°Ë¢´‰∫∫Â∑•Êô∫ËÉΩË∂ÖË∂äÔºå‰πãÂêé‰∫∫Á±ª‰∏çÊúçÔºåÁ∫¶AlphagoÂú®17Âπ¥‰∏éÂΩìÊó∂‰∏ñÁïåÂÜ†ÂÜõÊüØÊ¥ÅËøõË°åÁöÑ‰∏âÁï™Â±ÄÂØπÂºàÔºåÁªìÊûúAlphago‰ª•3-0ÂÆåËÉúÊüØÊ¥ÅÔºåÈöè‰πãGoogleÂÆ£Â∏ÉÔºåAlphagoÂ∞ÜÊ∞∏‰πÖÈÄÄÂá∫Âõ¥Ê£ãÂ±äÊâÄÊúâÊØîËµõÔºåÂπ∂Â∞ÜÊ∫ê‰ª£Á†ÅÂºÄÊ∫ê‚Ä¶     Êú¨Â•óÊöëÂÅáÁ≥ªÂàóÊïôÁ®ãÔºå‰ºö‰∏ÄÁõ¥Êõ¥Êñ∞ÔºåUPÊòØ‰∏™Êáí‰∫∫ÔºåÊ¨¢ËøéÂ§ßÂÆ∂ËØÑËÆ∫Âå∫ÂÇ¨Êõ¥~ Â≠¶‰π†‰∫§ÊµÅÁæ§Ôºö962995716ÔºàÂèØÈ¢ÜËßÜÈ¢ë‰∏≠ÁöÑËÆæËÆ°Á¥†ÊùêËΩØ‰ª∂Ê†∑Êú∫Ôºâ Ê¨¢ËøéÊù•Áæ§ÈáåÂ≠¶‰π†Ôºå‰∏çÊáÇÁõ¥Êé•ÈóÆÔºåÊØèÂ§©ÂÆöÊúüÁõ¥Êí≠Ôºå‰ª•‰∏äÂÜÖÂÆπÂùáÊù•Ëá™ËØæÂ†ÇËäÇÈÄâÔºÅÔºÅÔºÅ Tags:ÊäÄÊúØÂÆÖ,PSÂü∫Á°Ä,Â≠¶‰π†,ÂÖ¨ÂºÄËØæ,PSÊïôÁ®ã,Âπ≥Èù¢ËÆæËÆ°,PSÊïôÂ≠¶,ÈáéÁîüÊäÄÊúØÂçè‰ºö,PhotoshopÊïôÁ®ã,Á≥ªÁªüÂ≠¶‰π†  ( 4 min )
    Êñ∞ÂèëÊòéÔºÅÂæÄÈîÆÁõòÈáåÂ°ûËøõ68‰∏™È©¨ËææÔºü‰∏ñÁïå‰∏äÁ¨¨‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁîµÂä®ÂèØË∞ÉÈîÆÁõòÔºÅËûçÂêàÂÖâËΩ¥ÂíåÊú∫Ê¢∞ËΩ¥ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂàá‰ºòÁÇπÔºåÊàëÂ∞ÜÂÆÉÂëΩÂêç‰∏∫È©¨ËææËΩ¥

  • Open

    Debian ‰ºöËÄÉËôëÂú®ÂÆòÊñπÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Ê∑ªÂä†ÈùûËá™Áî±Âõ∫‰ª∂ÂêóÔºüÂ¶ÇÊûú‰ªñ‰ª¨ÊÉ≥Ëß£ÂÜ≥ Debian ÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫ÂëòÈáçÁÇπÊèêÂá∫ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåËøô‰ºº‰πéÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÂèØËÉΩÊÄß„ÄÇ Áî±‰∫é Debian Âú®‰ªñÁöÑ¬†ÂçöÂÆ¢¬†‰∏≠ËøòÊèêÂà∞‰∫ÜÂÖ∂‰ªñ‰∏Ä‰∫õÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÂåÖÊã¨Ôºö Áª¥Êä§ÂçïÁã¨ÁöÑÈùûËá™Áî±ÈïúÂÉèÈùûÂ∏∏ËÄóÊó∂„ÄÇ Áî±‰∫éÁº∫‰πèÈùûËá™Áî±Âõ∫‰ª∂ÔºåËÆ∏Â§öÁî®Êà∑‰∏çÂñúÊ¨¢ÂÆòÊñπÈïúÂÉè„ÄÇ     Ë∞∑Ê≠åÂ∑≤ÁªèÂπ≤Á†∏‰∫Ü 267 Ê¨æÁ°¨‰ª∂ ÊçÆ‰∏ÄÂÆ∂ÂõΩÂ§ñÁΩëÁ´ô‰∏çÂÆåÂÖ®ÁªüËÆ°ÔºåÈ¢ÑËÆ°Âà∞ÊòéÂπ¥ 3 ÊúàÔºàÊåâÁÖßË∞∑Ê≠åÁöÑÈ¢ÑÂëäÔºâÔºåË∞∑Ê≠åÁîª‰∏äÂè•Âè∑ÁöÑÁ°¨‰ª∂‰∫ßÂìÅÊúâ 267 Ê¨æ„ÄÇÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÂåÖÊã¨ Nexus ÊâãÊú∫Ôºà2012-2015Ôºâ„ÄÅË∞∑Ê≠åÁúºÈïúÔºà2012-2015Ôºâ„ÄÅË∞∑Ê≠å Cardboard VR Á∫∏ÁõíÔºà2014-2019ÔºâÁ≠âÁ≠â„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöTech Going ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöÁúãÊù•Ë∞∑Ê≠åËøòÈúÄË¶ÅÂú®Á°¨‰ª∂‰∏äËØÅÊòéËá™Â∑±Ôºå‰∏çËøá‰ºº‰πéËøô‰∫õÂè™ÊúâËãπÊûúÂú®Á°¨‰ª∂‰∏ä‰∏ÄÁõ¥‰øùÊåÅ‰∏çÈîôÁöÑÊàêÁª©ÔºåÂÖ∂ÂÆÉËΩØ‰ª∂Â§ßÂéÇÂ§ßÂ§öÂú®Á°¨‰ª∂‰∏äÁöÑÊàêÂäü‰∏çÂ¶ÇÂÖ∂ËΩØ‰ª∂„ÄÇ ÊºèÊ¥ûÊä´Èú≤ 15 ÂàÜÈíüÂêéÈªëÂÆ¢Â∞±ÂºÄÂßãÊâ´Êèè ÊúÄËøëÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰ªΩ‰∫ãÊïÖÂìçÂ∫îÊä•ÂëäÁß∞ÔºåÈªëÂÆ¢‰∏ÄÁõ¥Âú®ÁõëËßÜÂÆâÂÖ®ÂÖ¨Âè∏ÁöÑÊñ∞ÊºèÊ¥ûÊä´Èú≤Êä•ÂëäÔºåÈÄöÂ∏∏Âú® CVE ÂÖ¨Â∏É 15 ÂàÜÈíüÂêéÂ∞±ÂºÄÂßãÊâ´ÊèèÊºèÊ¥ûÔºåÂú®Êï∞Â∞èÊó∂ÂÜÖÂ∞±ËÉΩËßÇÂØüÂà∞È¶ñÊ¨°ÊºèÊ¥ûÂà©Áî®Â∞ùËØï„ÄÇ‰ª• 2022 Âπ¥ 5 Êúà 4 Êó•Êä´Èú≤ÁöÑ F5 BIG-IP ËøúÁ®ãÊâßË°åÊºèÊ¥û CVE-2022-1388 ‰∏∫‰æãÔºåÂú® CVE ÂÖ¨Â∏É 10 Â∞èÊó∂ÂÜÖÂ∞±ËÆ∞ÂΩïÂà∞‰∫Ü 2552 Ê¨°Êâ´ÊèèÂíåÊºèÊ¥ûÂà©Áî®Â∞ùËØï„ÄÇÊçÆËØ•Êä•ÂëäÔºå2022 Âπ¥‰∏äÂçäÂπ¥Âà©Áî®ÊúÄÂ§öÁöÑÊºèÊ¥ûÊòØ ProxyShell Âç† 55%ÔºåÂÖ∂Ê¨°ÊòØ Log4Shell Âç† 14%ÔºåSonicWall 7%ÔºåProxyLogon 5%„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöBleeping Computer ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºö‰ªé CVE ÂÖ¨Â∏É‰πãÊó∂ÔºåÂ∞±ÊòØÂÆâÂÖ®‰∏ìÂÆ∂ÂíåÈªëÂÆ¢ËµõË∑ëÁöÑÂèë‰ª§Êû™„ÄÇÊàëËßâÂæó‰Ωú‰∏∫ÂÆâÂÖ®‰∏ìÂÆ∂ÔºåÁúüÊòØÂ§™Èöæ‰∫Ü„ÄÇ Âçé‰∏∫Ê≠£ÂºèÂèëÂ∏É HarmonyOS 3 27 Êó•ÔºåÂçé‰∏∫Ê≠£ÂºèÂèëÂ∏É‰∫Ü HarmonyOS 3ÔºåÂ∞Ü‰∫é 9 ÊúàÂêØÂä®ËßÑÊ®°ÂçáÁ∫ß„ÄÇÁî®Êà∑Â∑≤ÁªèÂèØ‰ª•Áî≥ËØ∑ÊµãËØïÁâàÂ∞ùÈ≤úÔºåÊîØÊåÅÂ§öËææ 14 Ê¨æËÆæÂ§á„ÄÇÊà™Ê≠¢‰ªäÂπ¥ 7 ÊúàÔºåÊê≠ËΩΩ HarmonyOS 2 ÁöÑÂçé‰∏∫ËÆæÂ§áÁ™ÅÁ†¥ 3 ‰∫øÂè∞„ÄÇÊ≠§Ê¨°ÁöÑ HarmonyOS 3ÔºåÂçáÁ∫ß‰∏ªË¶ÅÂõ¥ÁªïË∂ÖÁ∫ßÁªàÁ´Ø„ÄÅÈ∏øËíôÊô∫ËÅî„ÄÅ‰∏áËÉΩÂç°Áâá„ÄÅÊµÅÁïÖÊÄßËÉΩ„ÄÅÈöêÁßÅÂÆâÂÖ®Âíå‰ø°ÊÅØÊó†ÈöúÁ¢çÂÖ≠Â§ßÊñπÈù¢„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöÈ∏øËíô ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöÊúüÂæÖ‰∫ÜÂæà‰πÖÁöÑÈ∏øËíô 3 Áªà‰∫éÂèëÂ∏É‰∫ÜÔºå‰Ω†ÂáÜÂ§áÂçáÁ∫ß‰Ω†ÁöÑÂçé‰∏∫ÊâãÊú∫ÂêóÔºü  ( 2 min )

    Âú® Ubuntu ‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî® Docker Compose ÂÆâË£Ö Docker ÂºïÊìéÁöÑÂàÜÊ≠•ÊåáÂØº„ÄÇ Âú®ËøôÁØáÊñáÁ´†‰∏≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Â∞Ü‰ºöÊòéÁôΩ Docker ÊòØ‰ªÄ‰πàÔºåÂ¶Ç‰Ωï¬†Âú® Ubuntu ‰∏≠ÂÆâË£Ö Docker ÂºïÊìé¬†„ÄÇÊ≠§Â§ñÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰πüÂ∞Ü‰ºöÊòéÁôΩÂ¶Ç‰Ωï¬†ÂÆâË£Ö Docker Compose¬†ÔºåÂÆÉÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆö‰πâÂπ∂ËøêË°åÂ§öÂÆπÂô®ÁöÑ Docker Â∫îÁî®„ÄÇ Êàë‰ª¨Â∑≤ÁªèÂú® Ubuntu 22.04 LTS ‰∏≠Ê≠£ÂºèÁöÑÊµãËØï‰∫ÜËøô‰ªΩÊåáÂçó„ÄÇÁÑ∂ËÄåÔºåÂÆÉ‰πüÂ∫îËØ•ÂØπÊóßÁâàÊú¨Â¶Ç 20.04 LTS Âíå 18.04 LTS ÊúâÊïà„ÄÇ‰∏∫‰∫ÜÊõ¥Â•ΩÁöÑÂÆâÂÖ®ÊÄßÂíåÁ®≥ÂÆöÊÄßÔºåÊàëÊé®Ëçê‰Ω†‰ΩøÁî®ÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑÁâàÊú¨ ‚Äî‚Äî Ubuntu 22.04 LTS „ÄÇ ‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØ Docker Ôºü Docker¬†ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Âø´Êç∑„ÄÅËΩª‰æøÁöÑÁ≥ªÁªüÁ∫ßËôöÊãüÂåñÊäÄÊúØÔºåÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÂíåÁ≥ªÁªüÁÆ°ÁêÜÂëòÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®ÂÆÉÊûÑÂª∫ÂÖ∑Â§áÊâÄÊúâÂøÖË¶Å‰æùËµñÈ°πÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÔºåÂπ∂Â∞ÜÂÖ∂‰Ωú‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂåÖÂèëÂ∏É„ÄÇ Docker ‰∏éÂÖ∂‰ªñÂ¶Ç VMWare „ÄÅXen „ÄÅ‰ª•Âèä VirtualBox Á≠âÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÁöÑËôöÊãüÂåñÊñπÂºè‰∏çÂêåÔºåÊØè‰∏™ËôöÊãüÊú∫‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÂçïÁã¨ÁöÑÂÆ¢Êà∑Êìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªü„ÄÇ ÊâÄÊúâÁöÑ Docker ÂÆπÂô®ÊúâÊïàÂú∞ÂÖ±‰∫´Âêå‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏ªÊú∫Á≥ªÁªüÂÜÖÊ†∏„ÄÇÊØè‰∏™ÂÆπÂô®ÈÉΩÂú®Âêå‰∏Ä‰∏™Êìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªü‰∏≠ÁöÑÈöîÁ¶ªÁî®Êà∑Á©∫Èó¥‰∏≠ËøêË°å„ÄÇ Docker ÂÆπÂô®ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®‰ªª‰Ωï Linux ÁâàÊú¨‰∏äËøêË°å„ÄÇÊØîÂ¶ÇËØ¥‰Ω†‰ΩøÁî® Fedora ÔºåÊàëÁî® Ubuntu „ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨ËÉΩÁõ∏‰∫íÂºÄÂèë„ÄÅÂÖ±‰∫´Âπ∂ÂàÜÂèë Docker ÈïúÂÉè„ÄÇ ‰Ω†Êó†ÈúÄÊãÖÂøÉÊìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªü„ÄÅËΩØ‰ª∂‰ª•ÂèäËá™ÂÆö‰πâËÆæÁΩÆÔºå‰ªª‰Ωï‰∫ãÈÉΩ‰∏çÁî®ÊãÖÂøÉ„ÄÇÂè™Ë¶ÅÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑ‰∏ªÊú∫ÂÆâË£Ö‰∫Ü Docker ÔºåÂ∞±ËÉΩÊåÅÁª≠ÂºÄÂèë„ÄÇÁÆÄË®Ä‰πãÔºåDocker ËÉΩÂ§üÂú®‰ªª‰ΩïÂú∞ÊñπËøêË°åÔºÅ ÂâçÊñá‰∏≠‰Ω†ËØªÂà∞‰∫Ü‰∏§‰∏™ËØçÔºöDocker ÈïúÂÉè¬†Âíå¬†Docker ÂÆπÂô®¬†ÔºåÊàñËÆ∏‰Ω†Âú®ÊÉ≥ÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÁöÑÂå∫Âà´„ÄÇ ÈÄö‰øóÂú∞ËØ¥ÔºåDocker ÈïúÂÉèÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊèèËø∞ÂÆπÂô®Â∫îËØ•Â¶Ç‰ΩïË°®Áé∞ÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂ÔºåËÄå Docker ÂÆπÂô®ÊòØ Docker ÈïúÂÉèÁöÑËøêË°åÔºàÊàñÂÅúÊ≠¢ÔºâÁä∂ÊÄÅ„ÄÇ Â∏åÊúõ‰Ω†ËÉΩÂ§üÁêÜËß£ Docker ÁöÑÂü∫Á°ÄÊ¶ÇÂøµ„ÄÇÊõ¥Â§öÁªÜËäÇÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )

    Sony starts testing 1440p support for PS5
    Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge Sony is starting to test 1440p resolution support for its PlayStation 5 console, a highly-requested addition. Testers will get access to a new PS5 system software beta today that includes 1440p support, curated gamelists for their library, and new social features. The new 1440p video output option will allow PS5 owners to choose this resolution on compatible TVs and monitors. If games support 1440p then native 1440p output will be supported, but otherwise 4K games will benefit from improve anti-aliasing by supersampling down to the 1440p output.     Digital Collages by Beto Val Splice Vintage Illustrations into Surreal Hybrid Creatures
    Ecuadorian artist Beto Val alchemizes vintage illustrations into bizarre compositions that blend fruits with fowl and aquatic life with land animals. Using imagery available through the public domain, Val cuts and repositions fins, wings, and scaly talons into surreal creatures: round owl faces peer out from pineapples, autumn leaves sprout from tropical birds, and a rendering evocative of a biological chart displays fish with bodies made of strawberries, brains, and an early, industrial locomotive. More  ( 5 min )

More  ( 5 min )

ÊâÄ‰ª•ÊàëÂèàË¢´ÂΩªÂ∫ïÁªïÊôï‰∫ÜÔºåÂÖ∂ÂÆûÂæà‰πÖÈÉΩÊúâÁÇπÊêû‰∏çÊòéÁôΩvmÊòØÂπ≤‰ªÄ‰πàÁöÑÔºå‰ª•Ëá≥‰∫éÂºÄÂèëÊàëÈÉΩ‰∏çÊï¢ÂÜôvm,ËôΩÁÑ∂ÂΩìÊó∂ÁªôÊàëÁöÑÂºÄÂèë‰ªªÂä°‰πü‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÂÜôËøô‰∫õÔºåÂè™ÊòØÊîπÂä®‰∏Ä‰∫õËÄÅÈ°πÁõÆÔºàÊ≤°ÊúâËøô‰∫õÊûÑÊû∂ÁöÑ‰π±‰∏ÉÂÖ´Á≥ü‰ª£Á†ÅÔºâÔºå‰ΩÜÊàëÁúüÊ≠£‰∫ÜËß£ÂÆÉ‰ª¨Ë¶ÅÂà∞Â∑•‰ΩúÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏â‰∏™Êúà‰∫Ü„ÄÇ # Ê∏êÂÖ•‰Ω≥Â¢É **ÊÄªÁªì** ÂÖ∂ÂÆûÊäÄÊúØ‰∏äÊàëÊ∑±ÂÖ•‰∫ÜËß£ÁöÑÂπ∂‰∏çÂ§öÔºåÂü∫Á°ÄÂΩìÊó∂‰πüÊ≤°ÊúâËá™Â∑±ÂéªÈáçÂ§¥Â≠¶‰∏ÄÈÅçÔºåËÄåÊòØÈöèÁùÄÂºÄÂèëËøêÁî®ËÄåÂèòÂæóÁÜüÁªÉÔºåÁÑ∂ËÄåËøôÊòØÊúâÁº∫Èô∑ÁöÑÔºåÂΩìÊó∂Áü•ÈÅìÁöÑÂõõÂ§ßÁªÑ‰ª∂ÔºåÂ¶Ç‰ªäÂÖ∂ÂÆûÂú®ÂºÄÂèë‰∏≠ÊàëÊé•Ëß¶Â§öÁöÑ‰πüÂè™ÊòØActivityÔºåÂÖ∂‰ªñÁöÑÂ¶ÇÂÜÖÂÆπÊèê‰æõËÄÖÔºàContentProviderÔºâÔºà‰∏™‰∫∫ÊÑüËßâÂ∞±ÊòØËá™Â∑±Âª∫ÁöÑmodelÔºâÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÊúçÂä°ÔºàServiceÔºâÔºåÂπøÊí≠ÔºàBroadCastÔºâÂÖ∂ÂÆûÈÉΩ‰∏çÊòØÂæà‰∫ÜËß£Ôºå‰ΩÜ‰πüÂ∞±Ëøô‰πàÂºÄÂèë‰∏ãÂéª‰∫ÜÔºåÁõ∏‰ø°Á≠âÂà∞Ëá™Â∑±ÈúÄË¶ÅÊó∂‰πü‰ºöÂø´ÈÄüÁêÜËß£ËøêÁî®ÁöÑ„ÄÇ  ( 5 min )
    [Flutter] ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÊàëÁöÑ ListView ÂèàÂèåÂèíÂèïÂ¥©‰∫Ü

Á∫¶Êùü Ë¶ÅÁü•ÈÅìËøô‰∏™ÈîôËØØÁöÑÂéüÂõ†ÔºåÈ¶ñÂÖàÊàë‰ª¨ÂæóÁúãÁúãFlutterÊòØÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÁ°ÆÂÆö WidgetÁöÑÂ∞∫ÂØ∏Â§ßÂ∞èÁöÑÔºå‰Ωú‰∏∫‰∏ÄÈ¢óÊ†ëÂΩ¢ÁªìÊûÑÁöÑÊ†ëÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑWidgetÂú®ËøõË°åÂ∏ÉÂ±ÄÊó∂ÔºåÊòØ‰æùÈù†RenderObjectÊù•ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂÆÉÁöÑÊ∏≤Êüì„ÄÅÁªòÂà∂ÁöÑÔºåËøôÂÖ∂‰∏≠Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûÂ∏∏ÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÂ±ûÊÄßÔºöÁ∫¶ÊùüÔºàConstraintÔºâ„ÄÇ Á∫¶ÊùüÔºåÊòØÁà∂WidgetÂØπ‰∏ãÂ±ÇWidgetÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™Â∞∫ÂØ∏Âª∫ËÆÆÂå∫Èó¥„ÄÇÂÆÉÁöÑÂΩ¢ÂºèÈÄöÂ∏∏ÊòØËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÔºö const BoxConstraints({ this.minWidth = 0.0, this.maxWidth = double.infinity, this.minHeight = 0.0, this.maxHeight = double.infinity, }) ‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    ComposeË¶ÅÊàë‰ª¨rememberÔºåÂà∞Â∫ïÊÄïÊàë‰ª¨Âøò‰∫ÜÂï•Ôºü
    Êê∫ÊâãÂàõ‰ΩúÔºåÂÖ±ÂêåÊàêÈïøÔºÅËøôÊòØÊàëÂèÇ‰∏é„ÄåÊéòÈáëÊó•Êñ∞ËÆ°Âàí ¬∑ 8 ÊúàÊõ¥ÊñáÊåëÊàò„ÄçÁöÑÁ¨¨1Â§©ÔºåÁÇπÂáªÊü•ÁúãÊ¥ªÂä®ËØ¶ÊÉÖ ÁúãËøáComposeÊ°à‰æãÊàñËÄÖÊ∫êÁ†ÅÁöÑ‰Ω†ÔºåÁõ∏‰ø°ËÇØÂÆöÊòØËßÅËøá remember ‰∫ÜÁöÑ„ÄÇÈ°æÂêçÊÄù‰πâÔºåComposeÊòØË¶ÅËÆ©Êàë‰ª¨ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†Å‚ÄúËÆ∞‰Ωè‚Äù‰∏úË•øÔºåÈÇ£Âà∞Â∫ïÊòØËÆ∞‰Ωè‰ªÄ‰πàÂë¢ÔºüË¶ÅÊòØ‰∏ç rememberÔºåÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÂäüËÉΩÂ∞±ÂÆûÁé∞‰∏ç‰∫Ü‰∫ÜÂêóÔºü Â∏¶ÁùÄËøô‰∫õÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÊù•‰∏ÄÊé¢Á©∂Á´üÂêß ÈöèÊú∫Ëâ≤ÊñáÊú¨ ÂÅáËÆæÊúâËøô‰πà‰∏Ä‰∏™‚ÄúÈöèÊú∫Â∫ïËâ≤ÊñáÊú¨‚ÄùÁöÑÈúÄÊ±ÇÔºöÂÆûÁé∞‰∏Ä‰∏™ TextÔºåÂÖ∂ËÉåÊôØËâ≤ÊØèÊ¨°ÂêØÂä®ÈÉΩÈöèÊú∫‰∫ßÁîüÔºå‰∏îÁîüÂëΩÂë®ÊúüÂÜÖ‰∏çÂèò Áî®ComposeÂèØ‰ª•ÂÆûÁé∞Â¶Ç‰∏ãÔºö private val items = arrayOf(Color.Red, Color.Gray, Color.Magenta, Color.Blue, Color.Green, Color.Cyan) @Composable fun ColorText(name: String) { val color = items.random() val clicked = mutableStateOf(0) Log.d("ct", "ui compose") Column { Text( text = "I'm colored: ${clicked.value}", modifier = Modifier .padding(16.dp) .background(color) .clickable { Log.d("ct", "clicked") clicked.value = clicked.value + 1 } ) ‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    NDK Á≥ªÂàóÔºà5ÔºâÔºöJNI ‰ªéÂÖ•Èó®Âà∞ÂÆûË∑µÔºå‰∏áÂ≠óÁàÜËÇùËØ¶Ëß£ÔºÅ
    theme: jzman Êê∫ÊâãÂàõ‰ΩúÔºåÂÖ±ÂêåÊàêÈïøÔºÅËøôÊòØÊàëÂèÇ‰∏é„ÄåÊéòÈáëÊó•Êñ∞ËÆ°Âàí ¬∑ 8 ÊúàÊõ¥ÊñáÊåëÊàò„ÄçÁöÑÁ¨¨2Â§©ÔºåÁÇπÂáªÊü•ÁúãÊ¥ªÂä®ËØ¶ÊÉÖ ËØ∑ÁÇπËµûÂÖ≥Ê≥®Ôºå‰Ω†ÁöÑÊîØÊåÅÂØπÊàëÊÑè‰πâÈáçÂ§ß üëç üëç üî• HiÔºåÊàëÊòØÂ∞èÂΩ≠„ÄÇÊú¨ÊñáÂ∑≤Êî∂ÂΩïÂà∞ GitHub ¬∑ Android-NoteBook ‰∏≠„ÄÇËøôÈáåÊúâ Android ËøõÈò∂ÊàêÈïøÁü•ËØÜ‰ΩìÁ≥ªÔºåÊúâÂøóÂêåÈÅìÂêàÁöÑÊúãÂèãÔºåÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÂÖ¨‰ºóÂè∑ [ÂΩ≠Êó≠Èîê] Â∏¶‰Ω†Âª∫Á´ãÊ†∏ÂøÉÁ´û‰∫âÂäõ„ÄÇ ÂâçË®Ä Âú® Android ÁîüÊÄÅ‰∏≠‰∏ªË¶ÅÊúâ C/C++„ÄÅJava„ÄÅKotlin ‰∏âÁßçËØ≠Ë®Ä ÔºåÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÁöÑÂÖ≥Á≥ª‰∏çÊòØÊõøÊç¢ËÄåÊòØ‰∫íË°•„ÄÇÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÔºåC/C++ ÁöÑËØ≠Â¢ÉÊòØÁÆóÊ≥ïÂíåÈ´òÊÄßËÉΩÔºåJava ÁöÑËØ≠Â¢ÉÊòØÂπ≥Âè∞Êó†ÂÖ≥ÂíåÂÜÖÂ≠òÁÆ°ÁêÜÔºåËÄå Kotlin ÂàôËûçÂêà‰∫ÜÂ§öÁßçËØ≠Ë®Ä‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰ºòÁßÄÁâπÊÄßÔºåÂ∏¶Êù•‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÁßçÊõ¥Áé∞‰ª£ÂåñÁöÑÁºñÁ®ãÊñπÂºèÔºõ JNI ÊòØÂÆûÁé∞ Java ‰ª£Á†Å‰∏é C/C++ ‰ª£Á†Å‰∫§‰∫íÁöÑÁâπÊÄßÔºå ÊÄùËÄÉ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢ò ‚Äî‚Äî Java ËôöÊãüÊú∫ÊòØÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂÆûÁé∞‰∏§ÁßçÊØ´‰∏çÁõ∏Âπ≤ÁöÑËØ≠Ë®ÄÁöÑ‰∫§‰∫íÁöÑÂë¢Ôºü ‰ªäÂ§©ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Êù•ÂÖ®Èù¢ÊÄªÁªì JNI ÂºÄÂèëÁü•ËØÜÊ°ÜÊû∂Ôºå‰∏∫ NDK ÂºÄÂèëÊâì‰∏ãÂü∫Á°Ä„ÄÇÊú¨ÊñáÈÉ®ÂàÜÊºîÁ§∫‰ª£Á†ÅÂèØ‰ª•‰ªé¬†DemoHall¬∑HelloJni¬†‰∏ãËΩΩÊü•Áúã„ÄÇ ËøôÁØáÊñáÁ´†ÊòØ NDK Á≥ªÂàóÊñáÁ´†Á¨¨ 5 ÁØáÔºå‰∏ìÊ†èÊñáÁ´†ÂàóË°®Ôºö ‰∏Ä„ÄÅËØ≠Ë®ÄÂü∫Á°ÄÔºö 1„ÄÅNDK Â≠¶‰π†Ë∑ØÁ∫øÔºöÊÄé‰πàÂ≠¶ & ÊàëÁöÑÁªèÈ™å 2„ÄÅC ËØ≠Ë®ÄÂü∫Á°Ä 3„ÄÅC ++ ËØ≠Ë®ÄÂü∫Á°Ä 4„ÄÅC/C++ ÁºñËØëËøáÁ®ãÔºö‰ªéÊ∫êÁ†ÅÂà∞Á®ãÂ∫èËøêË°å ‰∫å„ÄÅNDK ÂºÄÂèëÔºö 1„ÄÅJNI Âü∫Á°ÄÔºöJava ‰∏é Native ‰∫§‰∫íÔºàÊú¨ÊñáÔºâ 2„ÄÅÊ≥®ÂÜå JNI ÂáΩÊï∞ÔºöÈùôÊÄÅÊ≥®ÂÜå & Âä®ÊÄÅÊ≥®ÂÜå 3„ÄÅNDK Âü∫Á°ÄÔºöndk-build & CMake 4„ÄÅso Êñá‰ª∂Âä†ËΩΩËøáÁ®ãÂàÜÊûêÔºöÁêÜËß£ Android ‰∏≠ loadLibrary() ÁöÑÊâßË°åÊµÅÁ®ã 5„ÄÅso Êñá‰ª∂ÈÄÇÈÖç 64 ‰ΩçÊû∂ÊûÑÔºöGradle Êèí‰ª∂‰∏ÄÈîÆÊ£ÄÁ¥¢Êú™ÈÄÇÈÖçÈ°π 6„ÄÅso Êñá‰ª∂Âä®ÊÄÅÂåñÔºöÂä®ÊÄÅ‰∏ãËΩΩ 7„ÄÅso Êñá‰ª∂‰ΩìÁßØ‰ºòÂåñÔºöÊñá‰ª∂Á≤æÁÆÄ ‰∏â„ÄÅÂü∫Á°ÄÁêÜËÆ∫ 1„ÄÅËßÜÈ¢ëÂü∫Á°ÄÁêÜËÆ∫ 2„ÄÅÈü≥È¢ëÂü∫Á°ÄÁêÜËÆ∫ 3„ÄÅH.264‚Ä¶  ( 15 min )

    Top 3 Ways to Center a DIV with CSS üöÄ
    In this blog will go over three approaches of centering a div. The most difficult thing a web developer will ever have to accomplish is use CSS to center a div both horizontally and vertically. Classic approach Flexbox approach .myDiv { position: absolute; top: 50%; left: 50%; transform: translate(-50%,-50%); } .flex { display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; } .grid { display: grid; place-items: center; } Thank you for reading this article; do follow me for more.  ( 4 min )
    How I knew that going from engineering was right for me (and quick tips to figure it out)
    At some point, when engineers reach a level of seniority, they become curious about management. I am convinced that every individual contributor arrives at the point of getting larger-than-oneself ideas and wanting to use the insight they accumulated through technical work to lead teams. For years, management seemed a logical next step for a developer‚Äôs career, up to the point of a strongly-held belief that getting a manager‚Äôs title is a ‚Äúpromotion‚Äù. Only after having made an engineer-manager transition myself, I am confident this is false. When you are a manager, you stop being an active contributor or have to cut your workload and give up challenging tasks. Over time, you might discover your coding skills have deteriorated and realize you are behind on tech trends and best practices. A‚Ä¶  ( 11 min )
    tsParticles 2.1.4 Released
    tsParticles 2.1.4 Changelog Bug Fixes Fixed issue with destroyed containers, fixes #4385, fixes #4413, fixes #4534 Fixed issue with opacity and svg color replaced images, fixes #4532 Yesterday, I have also announced that React and Vue.js packages are changing names. This is something important because the old packages could become obsolete in the next months, it depends on how many work I need to maintain 6 packages instead of 3. You can read more in the article below tsParticles React and Vue packages are changing! Matteo Bruni „Éª Jul 27 „Éª 2 min read #javascript #react #vue #webdev tsParticles now has an official subreddit that you can find here: https://www.reddit.com/r/tsParticles/ It's another social that adds to the list, for asking support or participate in the development with new ideas or bug reports. Just for a reminder, all official social channels are: Discord Slack Telegram Reddit / tsparticles A lightweight TypeScript library for creating particles. Dependency free (*), browser ready and compatible with React.js, Vue.js (2.x and 3.x), Angular, Svelte, jQuery, Preact, Inferno, Riot.js, Solid.js, and Web Components ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è This readme refers to upcoming v2 version, read here for v1 documentation ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è tsParticles - TypeScript Particles Table of Contents Do you want to use it on your website?     Developing high-performing applications with Python‚Äôs FastAPI
    Python is extremely popular among professionals, and used all over the globe. It is an object-oriented programming language with a dynamic semantic. Python is mostly chosen for developing web apps because of its many additional libraries, helpful frameworks, and simplicity. Let‚Äôs look closer at one of the fastest Python web frameworks available. Combining Python and FastAPI leads to amazing results and chances to develop fast websites. FastAPI is a modern, fast (high-performant), web framework with built-in support for async endpoints for building APIs with Python 3.6+ based on standard Python-type hints. Stack Overflow 2021 Developer Survey. It is used by large companies like Uber and Netflix to develop some of their applications. FastAPI gives the following benefits: Open standards Fas‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    #TestCulture ü¶Ö Episode 14 - Test coverage problems
    ùó™ùóµùóÆùòÅ ùó∂ùòÄ ùòÅùó≤ùòÄùòÅ ùó∞ùóºùòÉùó≤ùóøùóÆùó¥ùó≤? Test coverage helps determine whether a test case is covering the application code and how much code is exercised when those test cases are runned. Test coverage enables testers to identify gaps at early stages, get better coverage and to remove redundant cases. It basically saves ùöùùöíùöñùöé and ùöñùöòùöóùöéùö¢. üëâ Function coverage: ùô∑ùöäùöú ùöéùöüùöéùöõùö¢ ùöèùöûùöóùöåùöùùöíùöòùöó ùöíùöó ùöùùöëùöé ùöôùöõùöòùöêùöõùöäùöñ ùöãùöéùöéùöó ùöåùöäùöïùöïùöéùöç? üëâ Statement coverage: ùô∑ùöäùöú ùöéùöüùöéùöõùö¢ ùöïùöíùöóùöé ùöòùöè ùöåùöòùöçùöé ùöãùöéùöéùöó ùöéùö°ùöéùöåùöûùöùùöéùöç ùöäùöóùöç ùöüùöéùöõùöíùöèùöíùöéùöç? üëâ Condition coverage: ùô∞ùöõùöé ùöäùöïùöï ùöåùöòùöóùöçùöíùöùùöíùöòùöóùöú ùöéùö°ùöéùöåùöûùöùùöéùöç ùöäùöóùöç ùöüùöéùöõùöíùöèùöíùöéùöç? üëâ Path coverage: ùô∑ùöäùöú ùöéùöüùöéùöõùö¢ ùöôùöòùöúùöúùöíùöãùöïùöé ùöõùöòùöûùöùùöé ùöãùöéùöéùöó ùöéùö°ùöéùöåùöûùöùùöéùöç ùöäùöóùöç ùöüùöéùöõùöíùöèùöíùöéùöç? ‚ö†Ô∏è Some methods are related, for example: Path coverage implies both instruction coverage and test point coverage; Instruction coverage does not imply test point coverage. But test coverage is challenging‚Ä¶ 2Ô∏è‚É£ ùô≤ùöûùöúùöùùöòùöñùöéùöõùöú can now use complex user paths with multiple data, on multiple devices and with multiple navigators. The need to perform multiple types of data tests, on access control of an application, on object' transitions subject to a workflow ùó∂ùó∫ùóΩùóπùó∂ùó≤ùòÄ ùó±ùó≤ùóΩùòÅùóµ ùóºùóª ùó≥ùòÇùóªùó∞ùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùóÆùóπ ùòÅùó≤ùòÄùòÅùòÄ. But also the ability to manage ùóÆ ùóµùó∂ùó¥ùóµ ùòÉùóºùóπùòÇùó∫ùó≤ ùóºùó≥ ùòÄùòÅùó≤ùóΩùòÄ. ‚òùÔ∏è 3Ô∏è‚É£ Manual validation is made by developers or project managers and takes ùòÅùóºùóº ùó∫ùòÇùó∞ùóµ ùòÅùó∂ùó∫ùó≤ ùó∞ùóºùó∫ùóΩùóÆùóøùó≤ùó± ùòÅùóº ùó±ùó≤ùòÉùó≤ùóπùóºùóΩùó∫ùó≤ùóªùòÅ ùóÆùó∞ùòÅùó∂ùòÉùó∂ùòÅùó∂ùó≤ùòÄ. ‚åõ On the other hand, regular changes of UI makes it hard to maintain automated tests. Time spent ùóØùó≤ùó∞ùóºùó∫ùó≤ùòÄ ùóµùóÆùóøùó± ùòÅùóº ùó∑ùòÇùòÄùòÅùó∂ùó≥ùòÜ ùòÅùóº ùòÄùòÅùóÆùó∏ùó≤ùóµùóºùóπùó±ùó≤ùóøùòÄ when it comes to creating and running tests, as well as the high cost of test-related services and infrastructure. üò® üìö ùïäùï†ùï¶ùï£ùïîùïñùï§: https://agilitest.com/challenges/test-coverage http://agilitest.com/cards/understand-what-to-test Thread on Twitter.  ( 5 min )
    External Debugging Tools 3: JMXTerm
    When tracking a bug we need to take a two pronged approach. Similar to tongs that wrap the buggy module from both sides and squeezes to find the problematic part. Up until now we discussed tools that are very low level. Some can be used to debug system level services. Today we‚Äôll discuss the other side of the stack but still a very advanced management tool. To understand this you need to understand the field we‚Äôre in. As developers we deal with code and applications. Deployment is for OPS/DevOps and the tooling they use is often alien to us. It‚Äôs not that they have bad tools. On the contrary, they have amazing tools. But they‚Äôre usually designed for massive scale. When you need to manage thousands of servers you need a way to control things in all of them. For that we need a different set ‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )
    Create a JavaScript 3D Box Chart with Rounded Edges
    Hello! So this is my first article here and wanted to show you how I created a simple but amazing animated 3D Bar Chart with dynamically colored bars based on their height. The chart is rendered using NodeJS, Visual Studio Code, and LightningChart JS' BoxSeries3D, a series type capable of rendering any number of Boxes as well as allowing single full-level modifications (location, size, color) at any point during the runtime. The example also shows how to use the rounded edges feature. This is a characteristic of this chart that is active by default but can also be disabled (if you use BoxSeries3D.setRoundedEdges). Ideally, you would download the project to follow this article. The file is a RAR and you can get it from here: 3D Box Series Project (RAR) For those who aren't yet familiar wit‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )
    What exactly is an API endpoint
    Just like the human bones connect with each other via the joint, likewise, an API connects two software, enabling them to interact and transfer data. API is an acronym for Application Programming Interface. To read more about API you should check here. Endpoints are the end path of a resource URL and usually have brief descriptions. Also, an endpoint shows how you can access specific information from a resource, not the base path shared by all endpoints. This is a common mistake people make most times, identifying an endpoint as URL is wrong. URL is a base path to the resource API, it can be associated with any HTTP method. An API URL Path is an address that allows you to access an API and its various features. It is the base address for a specific API that you‚Äôre using. Until you choose a‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )

    ‰∏Ä‰ª∂Â∞è‰∫ãÔºåÁôΩÊâî‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Èº†Ê†á
    iovekkk: Áî®‰∫Ü‰∏§Âπ¥Â§öÁöÑÊó†Á∫øÈº†Ê†áÔºåÂë®‰∏ÄÊó©‰∏äËøáÊù•ÂèëÁé∞ÁîµÊ±†Ê≤°Áîµ‰∫ÜÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÂéªÂÖ¨Âè∏ÂâçÂè∞ÊâæÊñ∞ÁîµÊ±† ‰∏ÄËøûÊç¢‰∫ÜÂ•ΩÂá†‰∏™ÁîµÊ±†ÔºåÈº†Ê†áÈÉΩ‰∏ç‰∫ÆÔºåÊàë‰ª•‰∏∫Èº†Ê†áÂùè‰∫Ü ÊÉ≥‰∏ÄÊÉ≥‰πüÁî®Êå∫‰πÖ‰∫ÜÔºåÈº†Ê†á‰πü‰∏çË¥µÔºåÂá†ÂçÅÂùó‰π∞ÁöÑÔºåÂùè‰∫ÜÂÄí‰πüÂêàÁêÜÔºåÈöèÊâãÂ∞±ÁªôÊâî‰∫Ü Ëø´‰∫é‰ªªÂä°Á¥ßÊÄ•ÔºåÊ≤°ÊúâÈº†Ê†áÂπ≤Ê¥ªÊïàÁéá‰ΩéÔºå‰∫éÊòØÁ´ãÂàªÂú®‰∫¨‰∏ú‰∏ãÂçï‰π∞‰∫Ü‰∏™Êñ∞Èº†Ê†áÔºå‰∏ãÂçà‰∏âÁÇπÂ∞±ÈÄÅÂà∞‰∫Ü ÁÑ∂ËÄåÊÑüËßâÊñ∞Èº†Ê†á‰∏çÂ§™Â•ΩÁî®ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Èöî‰∫ÜÂá†Â§©ÂèàÊääÂÆ∂ÈáåÁöÑÈº†Ê†áÊç¢ËøáÊù•Áî® ÂÆ∂ÈáåÁöÑÈº†Ê†áÁîµÊ±†Áî®‰∫ÜÂæà‰πÖ‰∫ÜÔºå‰πü‰∏çÁü•ÈÅìËøòÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÁîµÈáèÔºå ÊàëÂøÉÊÉ≥ÊèêÂâçÊç¢‰∏Ä‰∏ãÊñ∞ÁîµÊ±†ÂêßÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÂ∞±ÊääÂâçÂá†Â§©ÊãøÁöÑÈÇ£Âá†ËäÇÁîµÊ±†Êç¢‰∏Ä‰∏ãÔºåÁªìÊûúÈº†Ê†á‰πüÈÉΩ‰∏ç‰∫Æ ÊàëÁ™ÅÁÑ∂ÊÑèËØÜÂà∞ÔºåÂéüÊù•ÊàëÁöÑÊóßÈº†Ê†áÊ≤°ÊúâÂùèÔºåÊòØÊàëÊãøÁöÑËøôÂá†ËäÇÁîµÊ±†ÈÉΩÊ≤°ÊúâÁîµ‰∫Ü Ê∑¶ÔºÅ  ( 1 min )

    ZFS on Windows (using WSL2)
    oldshensheep: Ëøô‰∏™ËÆ© ZFS Â∑•‰ΩúÂú® Windows ‰∏äÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆËøò‰∏çÂ§™Á®≥ÂÆöÔºåÁªèÂ∏∏ËìùÂ±èÔºå‰æøÂØªÊ±ÇÂÖ∂‰ªñËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÔºå‰∫éÊòØ‰πé„ÄÇ Êúâ‰∫∫ÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöËØ¥‰Ω†Âú®‰∏çÊòØËÑ±Ë£§Â≠êÊîæÂ±ÅÂêóÔºåËøô‰∏çÂ∞±ÊòØË£Ö‰∏™ËôöÊãüÊú∫ËøêË°å Linux ÔºüÔºüÔºü ÊòØÁöÑÔºåÊàëÂ∞±ÊòØËÑ±Ë£§Â≠êÊîæÂ±Å„ÄÇ ÂÜôËøô‰∏™ÊñáÁ´†ÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄô‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑÊòØ ArchLinux ÁöÑ WSL2 Ôºå‰∏∫‰∫Ü‰ΩøÊïôÁ®ãÊõ¥ÁÆÄÂçïÔºå‰πü‰∏∫‰∫Ü‰ªé 0 ÂÆûÁé∞ÔºåËøôÁØáÊñáÁ´†‰ΩøÁî® Ubuntu22.04 ÁâàÊú¨ËøõË°åÊµãËØï„ÄÇ ÂÖàÂÜ≥Êù°‰ª∂ ÂÆâË£Ö WSL2 ÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑ Ubuntu22.04 ÔºåÂÖ∂‰ªñÁöÑÁ≥ªÁªüÁâàÊú¨Â∫îÂΩì‰πüÂèØ„ÄÇ ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂÆâË£ÖÊñπÊ≥ïÂèÇËÄÉÂÆòÊñπÊñáÊ°£„ÄÇ ÂØπ‰∫éÁ≥ªÁªüÁâàÊú¨Â§ß‰∫é Windows 10 version 2004 ÊàñËÄÖ Windows11 ÁöÑÁî®Êà∑ÂèÇËÄÉ‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑÊñáÊ°£Ôºö https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/install ÂØπ‰∫éÁ≥ªÁªüÁâàÊú¨Â§ß‰∫é Version 1903 ÁöÑÂèÇËÄÉ‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑÊñáÊ°£Ôºö https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/install-manual ÊõøÊç¢ WSL ÁöÑ Linux Kernel ÂèÇËÄÉÊñáÊ°£^1 Âú®Ê≠§ https://github.com/oldshensheep/zfs-on-wsl/releases ‰∏ãËΩΩÁºñËØëÂ•ΩÁöÑÊîØÊåÅ ZFS ÁöÑ Kernel ÔºåÈúÄË¶Å‰∏ãËΩΩ bzImage ÔºåÊîæÂà∞ Windows ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™Âú∞Êñπ„ÄÇ ÁÑ∂ÂêéÂú® PowerShell Á™óÂè£‰∏≠ÊâßË°å‰ª•‰∏ãÂëΩ‰ª§Ôºö Ê≥®ÊÑèÊääÊõøÊç¢Êàê‰Ω†‰∏ãËΩΩÁöÑ bzImage ÁöÑË∑ØÂæÑÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇC:\\Fun\\bzImage " [wsl2] kernel= " > ~/.wslconfig ÁÑ∂Âêéwsl --shutdownÂÖ≥Èó≠ËøêË°å‰∏≠ÁöÑÂÆû‰æãÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÈáçÊñ∞ÂêØÂä® Ubuntu „ÄÇ ÊåÇËΩΩÁ°¨ÁõòÂà∞ WSL2 ÂèÇËÄÉÊñáÊ°£^2 ÂÖ∂ÂÆûÁ≥ªÁªüÁé∞Âú®Â∑≤ÁªèÊîØÊåÅ ZFS ‰∫ÜÔºå‚Ä¶  ( 3 min )
    ÈÖçÁΩÆÊñá‰ª∂ËßÑÊï¥Âåñ

    Use this nifty Unix tool to process text on Linux
    Use this nifty Unix tool to process text on Linux Jim Hall Thu, 07/28/2022 - 03:00 1 reader likes this 1 reader likes this Unix has always excelled at processing text, and Linux is no different. And the tools to work with and transform text files still exist on all Linux systems. Like other computer systems, early Unix printed on paper, using a typewriter-style printing device. These printers provided limited formatting options, but with clever application of Unix tools, you could prepare professional-looking documents. One such tool was the pr tool, to prepare text documents for printing. Let's explore how to use standard Unix tools, such as the pr processor and the fmt text formatter, to prepare text files for printing on a typewriter-style printer. [ Read also:¬†How I use the Linux‚Ä¶  ( 9 min )

    Xbox is campy now
    Enjoying the outdoors, absolutely decked out in Xbox gear. | Image: Microsoft Xbox has released a clothing and accessory collection dedicated to camping. No, not the video game kind that esports organization 100 Thieves lambasted with its own clothing line ‚Äî Microsoft‚Äôs is about actually getting outside and touching grass. The camper collection includes a variety of shorts, shirts, and headgear, along with things like a hammock and camping chair. Given that most people don‚Äôt usually associate gaming with going outdoors, some of the items in the lineup actually seem decent. Xbox‚Äôs camp chair looks like a clone of the design popularized by the Helinox Chair Zero (to be fair, so does pretty much every other camp chair), but electric green and twice as heavy. Given that it‚Äôs significantly cheaper than the Helinox,... Continue reading‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    London paid a record price for electricity during its heatwave
    Photo by Richard Baker / In Pictures via Getty Images Last week, the UK reached its highest temperature on record ‚Äî 40 degrees Celsius, or more than 104 degrees Fahrenheit. On July 20th, as the record-breaking ‚ÄúRed Extreme‚Äù heatwave continued to linger, a Bloomberg op-ed reports officials made the decision to pay a record price of ¬£9,724.54 (about $11,685) per megawatt to ensure electricity for South London residents ‚Äî about 5,000 percent higher than its usual average price of ¬£178 per megawatt hour. To avoid an energy short squeeze in 2021, the UK paid about ¬£1,600 (more than $1,900) per megawatt to import energy. Yesterday #gas produced 43.0% of British electricity, more than wind 23.5%, nuclear 15.1%, biomass 7.2%, solar 6.0%, imports 3.8%, coal 0.8%, hydro 0.7%, other 0.0% *excl.... Continue reading‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )
    Spotify‚Äôs subscribers rise to 188M amidst podcasting setbacks
    Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge Spotify‚Äôs number of premium subscribers rose to 188 million in its second quarter, while its monthly active users (MAU) now sit at 433 million, the company announced in an earnings release today. That‚Äôs a year-over-year increase of 14 percent and 19 percent respectively, and compares to the 182 million and 422 million figures it announced last quarter. The company says its growth in MAUs was its largest ever in a second quarter, and exceeded its guidance. The earnings come at the end of a quarter in which Spotify‚Äôs big push into podcasts has experienced some hiccups. One of its biggest podcasts, Reply All, broadcast its final episode on June 23rd after co-hosts Alex Goldman and Emmanuel Dzotsi decided to leave production company Gimlet....     Independence Day director Roland Emmerich is making a gladiatorial epic for Peacock
    This is a picture from Independence Day‚Äôs sequel, but you get the idea. Roland Emmerich, the director behind disaster movies such as Independence Day, The Day After Tomorrow, and Moonfall, is making a ‚Äúgladiatorial epic‚Äù series for NBCUniversal‚Äôs streaming service Peacock. The show, which will be titled Those About to Die, is based on the book of the same name by Daniel Mannix (which, incidentally, previously served as the inspiration for Ridley Scott‚Äôs Gladiator). The series is set to be written by Robert Rodat, whose previous work includes Saving Private Ryan. Those About to Die is the first TV show created by Emmerich. Although he previously directed 2012 TV movie Dark Horse, the director‚Äôs career has otherwise been focused on the big screen, with a filmography packed with summer blockbusters. It sounds...
